cG5l8teICW5NRtRJ0GpMww.review_text: Festa's is my new #1 spot for karaoke in the city. I was a latecomer to Masae's takeover from Sachi, so I was surprised to see the remodel and the name change.  And things just got better from there.  Ken, the manager/bartender, brought us up to speed on the change. The place looks terrific now. More seating, better lighting (not brighter, just better), new karaoke system and much nicer staff.  There are several English books here, so it's not just Japanese songs.  Yes, the songs are $2 per, but worth the price.  You can now use a wireless mic if you don't want to sing on stage (unless it's super busy like last night and then only special people like me get to use the wireless; otherwise, it gets lost in the crowd).  I used to introduce a lot of people to Sachi's. I'll be stopping by even more often now.  UPDATE: And I'm bringing Mani.

h6wT6La3fOG0PuLPjmP2xQ.review_text: Ended up here a few months ago to meet up with friends who love this place, and I had a blast! Small, intimate but nice lounge (not gritty/divey), and because it's small it's more casual and fun, rather than feature some intimidating stage. Full bar plus lychee cocktails. I would've had fun just watching everyone and hanging at my table, but yes, we ended up singing. It felt like our own party after a certain point, with one guy from our group singing Sinatra and a bunch of us dancing up front. Great neighborhood spot if you can find it (it's just inside the Japantown mall).

dVribG2G7Ae3lgz66f3kpg.review_text: I know SF is an expensive place to live and run a business- but geeez! 6 dollar Sierra and 5 dollar BUD?? Im still giving them 3 stars because its a fun place to go with a nice decor.  I recommend getting there early to get a seat - and coming already tipsy will help your pocketbook.  The crowd was nice and friendly and the staff was good too.  I would go back when feeling like I didnt mind spending a hunk of cash to have fun time in a low key karaoke bar. By the way- they have a non-traditional song list so dont expect all your favorites will be there!

8Q0xnxT-KrvCl2pQF1qsFQ.review_text: So this place used to be Sachi, which i heard was pretty fun for Karaoke in a group setting...tonight was not the case.  I believe the new ownership just took over mid Dec and did a great job on the layout and design aspects of this very intimate lounge.  Had a fun time with Mike telling Aaron and I about how Nancy Pelosi has screwed up things for all us men in SF- being she is from here and that SF women are already very well u know where iam going with this.  I was cracking up all night on how animated and excited he was on Pelosi ruling the US.    Seating is comfortable and service was just above normal.  I think this place has potential, especially if more people discover this lil nook right across from Kinokuniya Bookstore.  Stuck with Gin&Tonic for the evening and had an okay cheeseplate.

KOWl_ZhqhYqY33-CbaJubw.review_text: "Making your way in the world today takes everything you've got.   Taking a break from all your worries, sure would help a lot.   Wouldn't you like to get away? Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name,  And they're always glad you came." ..........(Gary Portnoy, "Cheers" theme song)  I dedicate my 300th review to a place that I've visited over 100 times, sang at least 100 songs, and probably drank 100 drinks.  Why did it take me long to write this?  I must've been busy on their stage, or taking it EASY!  What draws me here on a weekly basis is the cozy setting, their friendly staff, and of course...Karaoke.  I always feel at home here.     I don't like singing in front of large crowds, and I usually prefer private karaoke rooms...but this place is intimate enough with a small lit stage, supportive crowd, and not bad of a sound system (considering the absence of a resident K-DJ).  Their extensive song selection isn't bad either.  They update with new songs every so often, but I tend to sing the older stuff anyway.  This place can get really packed on weekends, so don't expect to sing your songs close to closing time.    The bartenders are very down-to-earth, sincere, helpful, and fairly quick in making drinks upon order.  They do an exceptional job keeping the place clean, accommodating all their customers, creating a safe and fun environment for all.   This place is great for small private parties too.  Masae and staff are excellent in catering to their guests.    Some people call this place FIESTA on accident, and I think they nail it every time I hear that.  If I could come here every night, I would!  Actually, I think I have in multiple weeks.  I just hate leaving my heart in San Francisco.  Thanks to my duet partner, Ting A, for the introduction!

qrxiK9XxmBIlz0xuO6jRBA.review_text: This is a follow-up review - After 4 years and counting Festa remains the best, coolest, most authentic Karaoke bar in SF - bar none.  The bartenders know their stuff, so a visit to Festa is a good occasion to try something exotic - and it doesn't hurt your performance either.

5mqVb1VI-S6WzVALebRLQw.review_text: $5 sprites and unfriendly staff.  One star for cool location.  I think this place is homophobic.  C'mon this is SF, haven't you ever seen a drag queen before?

jzaJsPcfkjphAeR8mNZEVg.review_text: Hey! I want to Festa with several friends last night again that was packed even on Thursday night, wow!! Understandable for its super fun venue to sign and drink! The staff were so cool to serve us even it was very busy and they even looked having fun! I like the fact that other customers were also fun feeling like my own friends. I will write again when I go again to Festa that would be very soon!!

vTugBdYg34rX4KvGpzBrNA.review_text: This is a super cool spot for karaoke...well for watching other people. The bartenders selected a song for us, and it was so bad that we got booed off lol. However besides that, these are definitely some of the nicest bartenders in the city- a boy kept buying me shots and drinks, and I because they could tell I didn't want any of them (or need anymore), they kept swapping them out for non-alcholic versions. That was definitely a first. The only downfall was that I almost got my ass kicked by a very scary girl. I accidentally spilled a little of my drink on her purse and she was not happy about it. Luckily a random guy spent his time doing damage control and talked her out of it. How sweet!

8pONVRF4HDD9ynt5lCynTQ.review_text: I LOVE watching douchebags and B&T sorority girls get drunk and beg for attention as much as the next person, but this is going a little far. I felt like I was in a bar in Lafayette during Spring Break and all the seniors were home to get drunk and screw like they did back in high school.  However, if you have friends like mine, the Party Olympics will be easily won and before you know it, the Chets and the Chips and their drunk groupies will disappear (possibly dropping all of their money for you on their way out- thanks again!) and you will be left with a cozy bar, a little stage, and a decent sound system and song selection (this is karaoke, bitches).   Drinks cost a fortune (as in- you're likely to promise your first born in exchange for a well drink) and they're not that strong. So it's a good thing those yuppies got sloppy and left my dog and I with fistfuls of cash to cover all those vodka sodas. Good times! And right near my house. Three stars.

j4HYyybTRy6uOa46co8EdQ.review_text: Festa is always fun. The drinks are pricey and I've never been to a karaoke bar that charges patrons to sing, but I'd still consider this one of my favorite karaoke bars in the city for its intimate ambiance, friendly bartenders and extensive(-ly cheesy) song list.  BONUS: Last I went, a super-drunk Gavin Newsom-lookalike bought the entire bar a round of shots. Hope he comes back soon, too!

Jc0T3q_8bOjg9pPlJb3MBQ.review_text: Pros:  -A great variety of songs -Great drinks -Good atmosphere  Cons: -Very small place -Karaoke should be fun, but it seemed like it was an American Idol competition that night. -Drinks were expensive

T4jjNW_6HFQNXwD3eeBhAg.review_text: Festa is my favorite place for karaoke. Friendly staff, great drinks and good selections of songs. They always update the songs too. People are always supportive and fun no matter how good or bad you sing. If you like to sing this is the place!

Q0qo1Gi99LihNjitnpfCAw.review_text: If you're looking for a chill, divy karaoke bar, this is your place!  It's a very small, and intimate establishment, but the perfect place if you just want to have some drinks, sing and have fun.  The crowd is mixed, so you'll get a wide range of songs sung throughout the evening.  You pay per song, and songs are $2 each.

Wcksq23HgF45mPFZOUFy6g.review_text: I LOVE Festa! The people here are so nice. It's in Japantown (and I love Japantown). Oh, and the ambiance is just the best among karaoke bars - I love the city lights and stars along the walls and that you can look out the window over the street. The music selection is good, too. I almost always find the songs I want to sing. :)

pdilmEaeXuntV4eTnc9KcQ.review_text: Had a fun time singing "Anyway You Want It".  Did you ever try to karaoke a Journey song?  No.  Well, Steve Perry can sing.  Or could sing.  And I'm no Steve Perry, but I try, except without the mullet and the cheesy 80s moustache. Small place.   Cool stage backdrop good for pictures.   Has Hawaiian songs in the book too.

itXMelaTleEjLIFWCJtnwg.review_text: As we piled out of the taxi onto the sidewalk, we could hear the rest of our clan in joyful choruses: "Doooon't stop belieeevin'. Hold on to that feeel-ayayayin." We looked around for the entrance to Festa and merriment, and were like: How the hell do you get inside??  Luckily, the night's previous cocktails hadn't dimmed us enough to prevent discovering that the shopping mall entrance is the gateway to Festa. Up the staircase and round the corner, sure enough, we found the cubby-hole bar with a cityscape stage. The two bartenders were really nice, though there was the occasional drink mix-up. HIghballs seemed to run around $7.   It's $2-per-song, and the books have everything from show tunes to goldie oldies to pop. We heard it all too... yes, even a rousing closing rendition of All That Jazz (cue: jazz hands).

Omomh1jRNEi8L6-osElVxw.review_text: I think this place is pretty good...despite the really bad drinks.  The mixed crowed is great--from young hipsters to old fogies (like me).  It welcomes all.  I'm not a karaoke fan, but with a stage and "city lights" Festa is the place I could be converted.  But shaken manhattans and warm martinis at Tokyo prices don't help. With better bartenders, Festa could rock--even with an off pitch riff of Britney.

K_sMuRAvaXRHP1nBSajxRQ.review_text: Dropped in here on a whim after dinner in Japantown.  It's a small venue, very intimate.  Upon being seated, they ask you if you're going to be singing and hand over a song book.  The crowd is entertaining (mostly drunk) and the drinks somewhat original.  Unfortunately, because the crowd is so small, you end up seeing the same people onstage over and over again.  I did not have the courage (not drunk enough) to get up on stage....

4_raRCaI4wuheAgO7RtFCQ.review_text: YES.   A karaoke place that has The Darkness? Green Day? Red Hot? Nirvana?  All the songs I've ever wanted to sing at a Karaoke bar. Not that I'm raggin' on asian tunes or 80's classic (I did a beautiful job on Mike's "Rock with you" before my voice gave out to the high notes only he can master!) but it's really really nice that they included a lot of the....unusual fare. That right there was 4 stars.   The get up and go rotation of songs is the fun part I think: getting up in front of your friends and a bunch of strangers is nerve racking (plus there are some pro frequenters too! Some dude was killin' it on stevie wonder!) but its great fun just lettin' loose. I think people will have a better time if you're not trying so hard you know? You have a good time, everyone has a good time. Words to the wise indeed.   I couldn't blame em for the rest: the major wait times, the fairly weak cocktails: they're just they way they are. Man that long island was some turrrable business though. Glad I only had a beer. Gotta protect the voice to swoon the ladies! hahaha.   Its 2 bucks a song and the drinks are a bit pricey (6 for a bottle of saporro? meh...) but pro tip: get your song list in order. If you want to sing 10 songs, write down 10 songs. If you decide mid way through, tough luck if you got a pretty nice crowd building up. Stake your claim and just relax for the rest of the night! That's what I'm doin' next time.

9pF7_fqg8T8HdTtWggZYcA.review_text: Fairly good music selection.  Great ambiance.  Love the staff.  Horrible martinis that have too much vermouth --- other drink options are good.  Will come back often.

2b_VpbCZGiWic0kLSei4ZA.review_text: Expensive drinks. $2 per song. Will not provide free ice water without harassing you about the drink minimum (which I had already met in spades).  Attitude after receiving 16% tip on sub-par service.  Normally I have fun here but it seems lately the service/vibe has been totally off.

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: this place was way smaller than i anticipated!  i came for a bday party last wknd and had a lot of fun!  there are a lot of song choices, but they are a bit difficult to find in the huge books.  each song costs $2 to sing, so it makes for a pretty cheap evening.

I2uNXg4uOhZyPq-a3FmLsg.review_text: I went here a week ago for my first karaoke experience in the Bay area. I come from Las Vegas, where karaoke nights and bars are a-plenty and generally free (with a small tip for the DJ being recommended) -- so the $2 charge after 9pm was kind of strange, but I'm not going to fuss over $2.  If you are with the right group of people, this place is awesome. We came for a friend of a friend's going away party, and the whole place was made up of our group and one other party. The drinks were flowing (and poured heavily), everyone was in a good mood, everyone cheered each other on.  Their drinks were a bit expensive - $8 for a well vodka and cranberry - but if you can afford it, the service and atmosphere was worth the cost.  Come with a good group of friends and you'll be alright.

vLqbQkcSkvbWJRB96UTAsA.review_text: I had so much fun here. It's small, chill and super friendly :)

zMDJYPyZhgkXl6WvRQvsNA.review_text: Such RUDE people...   Here's what exactly the people working there saying:   "ok, we fuck'in lost your song... if you can write down the song number again we will put it in the queue..."   Ugh... after waiting there for 2 hours ordering drinks and tipping the bar tenders big time, and wondering what was going on, this is our answer for keeping us waiting forever? After such long wait and horrible service/attitude, who still wants to continue to sing there?  I ordered 3 songs at the same time, 2 of them played after about waiting there for an hour. I went up there saying that I ordered 3 songs all at the same time, is the 3rd one forgotten? and put down the 4th one. I was told that she could not play my songs all the time had to play others too, so I had to wait, it would be my turn after another 6 songs. After 6 songs, I went up there and asked again, she said it would be mine the next. After another a few rounds seeing others singing back to back, we thought it was not right. I went up there for the 3rd time to ask, the gal who was in charge of running the songs said: "see others were tipping us and you never give us tips!" AH...there were reasons behind it...  So we explained that we had been tipping the bar tenders big time... however, apparently, she randomly throw out my 3rd song, it was no longer even in the queue any more...   At that point, we felt so sick with these rude people. We asked for refund - really rather not to deal with them... she threw the money on the counter with another one song's refund short...   I will never return that place again. If you do not want to ruin your fun night, don't ever bother go there.

ahVwnO5O_AqY2PaZbnBW1w.review_text: I come here a lot. I really like this joint cause of the karaoke, ambiance, and bartenders are cool. Sunny is an interesting character, he's one of the bartenders there. I love it when he sings L.O.V.E. I like the little stage too. I have a great time singing up there, I feel like a pop star sometimes! they also have newer songs than most karaoke spots I've been to in the past.

SxyI2BAJm-S-SSJoMNvfkw.review_text: Went here for a friends birthday and it looked really cool. Intimate stage, good crowd, and a large hot sake was $10. I was ready for a good night. My friends and I put our songs into a tall gay asian man and then we waited. 3 hours later my song never comes up, I ask the man where I am at in line, to which he just looks at me and points to the trash. Now I had never done anything to this man nor acted rudely to justify his behavior. I spent $40 on drinks, gave up my seat to a nice couple who had been standing and was in a smile mood all night but apparently only generous tips to the diva with the karaoke machine will allow you to have fun on stage with friends. If I was looking for a diva with a karaoke machine I would have gone to The Mint, at least there the singers are amazing AND you actually get to sing.

pxnaGI13FrogazowZy-Lxg.review_text: Drinks are expensive but the atmosphere was great. I'll def come back to sing and laugh. However, the space is small and you could feel a little cramped inside if you're uncomfortable with small spaces. But i think that's part of the intimacy and attraction of this place.

ZSretWXlve11q9hP6SrScQ.review_text: A karaoke bar that puts that boom boom pow in their cocktails

Syt_iQqW_c9T2_lrvsddqQ.review_text: Festa turned out to be a swell place for a recent Sunday evening bday gathering. I see from their info that they'd like to charge you $100-$150 an hour to have a private party but on a Sunday you might just *cough* tell all your friends to show up and presto change-o you pretty much got the joint to yourselves especially if you've got a bunch of show-tune loving queens cuz the room is small and nobody is gonna want to hone in on your action. Or be near you and your Annie-Guys-n-Dolls-Seven-Brides-For-Seven-Brothers loving chums. Probably. But I'm not one to gossip and you didn't hear that from me.   Minus a half-star for the sourpuss owner lady, (crack a smile, you're in the hospitality industry whether you like it or not) and minus another 1/2 star for the expensive drinks. Well at least I can tell you the least expensive glass of wine is $9 and that is one kind of wine the others are all much pricier. I imagine the cocktails are 'spensive too tho I did see some manual mint muddling going on so, you know, that drives the flavor and the price up.

jgi0iam1b2XEqYAQBP7NRQ.review_text: 4.5 stars as a karaoke spot, but I'll give them 5 because it's more than a karaoke bar: it's an awesome place to have some drinks and watch people with wonderful voices sing. It's small and it's not too loud. So, you can have drinks with friends in a comfortable environment, and enjoy the show. The staff is friendly, and the regulars are hilarious -- they clearly practice for performing on the stage at Festa. Drinks are a little pricey for the quality, but you're getting a show too.  Really fun place!  My one complaint is that they charge $2 a song after a certain hour (8pm?) even if there is clearly no one singing and few people in the bar. I'm grumbly about disincentivizing people from singing, when I came there to watch people sing (and that's why I'm paying a little more for booze).

zSFkfZWK3BgmsWUQvZGPHA.review_text: This review should be prefaced by an admission:  I love Japan.  I don't mean I love Japan the way a person might love water skiing or chili dogs.  I love Japan the way you loved the girl you had a crush on in seventh grade.  About a year after I moved to Japan, I realized that if Japan had been personified as a woman, I would have either married her or gotten arrested by the Japanese Godzilla-helmet wearing police for stalking her, depending on how I did.  (And no, I didn't marry a Japanese woman as a way of fulfilling that strange desire and projecting it onto a person...that would have just been weird.)  So instead, in the many years since I've been back in America since living there, whenever I wander into places that are truly Japanese, I have a feeling of nostalgia that colors my judgment.  That would explain my behavior at Festa the other night.  Or it could be the drinks.  Both are perfectly plausible explanations.  So for starters, it's in Japantown and the bar is populated primarily by Japanese people.  I speak Japanese almost fluently (take note, Nance W. :) )  but of course, no one expects me to, so I get in what we used to call the 'language bubble' in these places.  The language bubble is a situation where nobody expects you to speak a certain language, so they feel free to speak in that language, often in ways they wouldn't if they knew you could understand them.    I knew this was a real Japanese karaoke bar for two reason:  the menu was small and had overpriced 'sunaku' (that means 'snacks') including the 'assorted plate' for $10, which was about 7 grapes, some cheese and crackers straight from nabicso and some kamaboko slices (don't ask.)  The second and more important reason is that everyone was doing what karaoke is really for:  humiliating themselves equally.  It's one of the ways of leveling society in Japan.  You bow to people all day higher or lower based on your social status in Japan, but once you're at the karaoke bar, everyone sucks equally, even the boss.  It's a pretty awesome tradition.  After a couple of fun-loving, corn-fed midwestern gals left the place after singing everything in the Michael Bolton catalog, it was time to get down to business.  Japanese songs were sung.  French 75s from earlier in the evening were impairing my ability to read kanji, and I never got around to singing my favorite Japanese karaoke song, 'Shima Uta.'  Buy me a drink there sometime and I'll do it.  Instead, I was pushed up onstage and made to sing (I forgot about this but it happens a lot) Elvis.  I decided that the thing to do was to just fully own it, so when 'Jailhouse Rock' came up, I just rocked that joint.  To paraphrase Samuel Jackson, to them I was Elvis.  Then came 'Are You Lonesome Tonight?' which was fine until I realized there's about a 2 minute speech in the middle of that song.  ("I wonder if...you're lonesome tonight..."  Itunes it if you've never heard that part.)  Anyway, it was effective, judging by the reaction of the bartender, but after that we still had to take it up tempo, as one more sappy tune like that would have killed me.  Finally, we got , as all white people in a Japanese karaoke bar must, to the Beatles.  After one rendition of  "If I fell," I wanted to try it again, with my college buddy singing harmony, so from the stage, with microphone in hand, I asked them to play it again, but I spoke Japanese.  This was almost more than the room could bear.  What kind of a freak was I?  The language bubble was thoroughly popped, but the rockin' still didn't stop.  Finally, at the end of the night, the bill was inexplicably a lot higher than we thought, which almost brought a tear of joy  to my eye because that's always what happens in Japan too.  Plus, I wasn't paying.  Don't go to Festa (or any Japanese karaoke bar) hung up on singing well, or you'll make a jackass of yourself.  Just remember three words the local barkeep at the karaoke place where I lived used to say to us:  you must enjoy.  That's right.  You MUST enjoy.  The most Japanese thing of all is that just because it's fun doesn't mean you have a choice.  Festa is definitely on my list of places I must enjoy again when I'm in SF.

SQoQOFZcyrgasZ4_5_l5Qg.review_text: Brace yourself... this place is SMALL (maybe 400 square feet) and you have to be BOLD about karaoke. The selection is extensive, the sound is great, and -- for first timers -- the karaoke holds your hand well. May we recommend doing what our friend Ahmed did and renting the joint for a couple of hours, filling it with friends who are VERY good singers, and enjoying the drinks and ambiance? I only wish Festa had one or two REALLY good beers on tap and maybe something to nibble, since it's a bit of a umbrella-in kinda frou-frou cocktail bar... drinks fine for "Xanadu" and "Homeward Bound," but not as good for "Foxy Lady!"

ee2ALG_x2ZC20uwF4D6n4Q.review_text: Wanting to sing a little to wind down a long night, I headed to Festa. I am starting to become a regular at this place for several reasons. The service is cool. The owner, Masae, is perfect to run this place. The setting has improved 100% over the previous management. They have a good selection of my favorite songs. The karaoke system works well. Stage and wireless mics. Cool patrons. It just feels at home.   The bartender of the night was cool. He sported sideburns that were long, and looked as if they could double as knives, LOL!!! After a few beers, he whipped up my Blue Tokyo, in layers. It was a pretty drink to look at, and tasted great.    Being a slow night, made it easy to get on the mic, but I must say that this place is fun when you have a lot of people who really get into the singing aspects.

58dvonndIVTMue5jJdJPFA.review_text: Awesome place for a song and sake.  The bartenders are super nice.  I went there a few weeks back with my drunk buddette from the Lower Haight, gave the bartender a tip to bump us up the line for a song and lo and behold, my friend was too drunk to sing.    Then I went back last week and guess what...Marina folks!  A group of Banana Republic dress shirts/jeans guys and their Gap wearing girlfriends took over the right side of the bar being obnoxious and drunk.  The best part is everyone in the bar was laughing at them because they thought that they were so kool.

vxR_YV0atFxIxfOnF9uHjQ.review_text: My new favorite local drinking place... Of course, since it is close to home that is a plus.  The bartenders are nice... drinks and pours are not as heavy as I would like, but everything in moderation right?     I do not sing, so I just sit at the bar, and talk to whoever my drinking buddy is that evening.  Since I do not know Japanese, if they sing badly or good in Japanese, I wouldn't be able to tell.  But I can tell if people sing badly in English.  And let me tell you... it can get pretty bad.  Just imagine drinking so much you are compelled to pay the $2 surcharge to sing a song.  Well sometimes it ain't pretty.  I'm not passing any judgment because as long as they are having a good time, it's cool with me.  Who knows, maybe one evening I will get piss drunk and sing, "Baby one more time" by Britney

n-LZIcHGmWfRl1GwdNlFzQ.review_text: True Pros -Very small & intimate venue which means lots of song time -Very friendly staff who check in occasionally -Never too crowded -Dancing, wandering, & having fun with the mic are all totally acceptable (no uptight dj)  True Cons -Drinks could be stronger -Single venue? -An additional mic and air instruments would make it better -Fancy cityscape background  So why 5 stars... You come with a party of 6+ people, and the stage is pretty much yours. It's just always fun.

GXSbU3uyKGEYsz0gKJ95iA.review_text: Assholes. Expensive drinks. Terrible karaoke. They were terrible to us, and didn't let us sing. The KJ was awful. We paid him $10 to sing three songs... And he didn't put us on in three hours. We were at the front of the song line for two hours and the KJ kept telling us there were a lot of other people waiting. Try Encore instead.

EFa2cyL13XY85o2bw4pajQ.review_text: This is a quaint little karaoke bar in Japantown, in the Kinokuniya building plaza area.  I remember a couple years ago it was dark and tired, with ancient Japanese patrons belting out oldies on stage.  Now its updated, better lit, and filled with younger folks singing their hearts out in front of everyone, publicly humiliating themselves like the karaoke gods intended.  The big Japanese beers here are ten bucks.  A carafe of cold sake will set you back about thirty bucks.  Being the Asian math whiz that I am I asked my drunken buddy from LA, would you rather have another sake or 3 big bottles of beer?  Not the math whiz but a practical fellow of course he picked quantity over quality.  I came here again with another friend from LA, in town for training this week.  She was dying to go out since she has 3 kids and her husband hates dancing, which is normal, doesn't drink, which is kinda abnormal, and doesn't like making a fool of himself in public singing karaoke, which hmmmm, is kinda normal.  I ordered a glass of sake and she got the lichee cocktail.  Oh the lichee was incredibly good.  So I made a pact with her.  I'll continue ordering sake for myself and foofoo drinks for her.  Then I'll drink half her drinks and we'll go through the entire foofoo menu... that way I can secretly indulge in my foofoo drink passion while maintaining some semblance of my masculinity.  Finally I gave up and just ordered myself a foofoo drink.  I just drank my pear cosmo like the man that I am... whatever that means.    Overall the lichee cocktail was by far the best.  An extra star for that plus the cool vibe.

oddhpGKipWerYXKScmlYVg.review_text: Pros: cozy atmosphere, near home, nice staff Cons: pricey drinks and charges per song, outdated song selections (especially for Japanese songs)

Lr-B-r-KF80yFy-2u336bw.review_text: I rolled to Fiesta with the Yelp Posse after the Elite event at Barrelhouse .  Its Bobby L. hangout and that boy can SING!!! Its a small intimate place in J Town . It reminded me of one of the Karaoke Places from the movie Duets.   Its a place to have a few drinks cut loose and just have fun and sing .   It has a Unisex Restroom.   The Bartenders run the Karaoke Machine.  At  times its can be a Yelpers Hangout.

HshIhF76Uea0-2ht_KUisw.review_text: The only reason this place gets 2 stars is because it's small and dispenses alcohol, thus enabling me rock out to NIN in front of strange 50 year old men.  I would really chalk that up to beer and patronage, though...  Ordering a drink here must be a joke.  In theory, there are two bartenders.  Keep in mind that this place is the size of a large closet.  Not only do the bartenders ignore you while you wait at the bar to order, but when you actually lean over, wave them down and ask politely to order a drink, they still ignore you.  It's so absurd, I have to assume they think I shat on their shoes a few minutes prior.    When I finally forced myself upon one of them and ordered 2 drinks, they gave me one.  I had to do the whole song and dance again (with no one else at the bar!) to get the other.  I then asked to open a tab.  They ran the credit card and gave it back right away.   The whole joke of a process took 20 minutes.  They also charge for songs intermittently.  One song is $2, the other is $3, and the other is free.  Oh, and the drinks that take 20 minutes to order?  Overpriced and small.

DfmtZlDE8JJv-boorp1PAg.review_text: Doing Karaoke and playing Rock Band are simply NOT the same thing! I can now say that with first-hand knowledge, having finally visited Festa, my first-ever Karaoke bar.   Does singing in the shower count by way of preparation?  Sure!  Will enough practice with Rock Band let you swagger up on stage and start belting them out like Bruno Mars?  It can't hurt (and for that matter, neither does a few rounds of Dutch Courage), but at the end of the day, there's absolutely nothing like singing in front of a live audience. I always wanted try Karaoke, but I never did; then I joined Yelp.  Some Yelpers are terrified of Karaoke, some are passing fond of it, and some (like my friend Bobby L., who's "The Duke" of Festa) were born with a mike in their hand and a song in their heart.  The Elite of the Elite Yelpers all have one thing in common though - they'll try almost anything once! At the tail-end of a Winter night earlier this year, a car-load of uber-Elites and I drove to this very-well hidden bar in Japantown.  Earlier that night, we had visited Little Star for some world-class deep-dish pizza yelp.com/biz/little-star…, then moved on to Cantina for some premium pre-Karaoke fortification.  I was feeling well-fed, well oil, and ready to wrestle 'gators when we arrived at the strip mall that contained Festa. It's a good thing Bobby L., was driving - I never would have found the place in a 1000 years, even with the nav app in my Droid; well hidden doesn't begin to describe this bar!  Bobby could have found it in his sleep (and he probably has a few times) - displaying the ease of long practice, he guided us unerringly to the door.  We all walked in, and I took a look around. The space is decidedly not big, about the size of an airport lounge; it has a small stage, with a twinkling city skyline backdrop, and a few tables huddled around it.  There's a bar against one wall.  The vibe is dive-bar intimate, and the crowd is friendly and supportive.   Got any particular song in mind for your Karaoke debut?  They probably have it here!  There are 4 huge song books which are alphabetized by song title, artist, or language.  One of my friends started leafing through the book looking for a tune; I glanced over her shoulder, and saw "That'll Be The Day" by Buddy Holly - I remembered most of the words (heck, there are only about six of 'em) so that was my choice! It's $2 per song, and no "official" DJ, so watch the prompter for your song - when it starts, you're on!  One by one and in pairs (duets are no problem here) my friends did the deed; then it was my turn.  I grabbed the mike, jumped up on stage, and sang for all I was worth... While I probably could have scared The Dead with my caterwauling, I lived to tell the tale.  I got a real kick out of the Karaoke experience, and I'm sure I'll be trying it again in the not-to-distant future. Festa is a great place for first-timers and veterans alike.  As this visit broke my Karaoke cherry, and I now fall into the latter category, I'll be back!

zyLIp7DRFqeIE1Grrh3Zng.review_text: They have "Sure Thing" now... and I ripped it.  What a night!

Plf9SP6LVqg7mVU3DgaX8w.review_text: I've walked past this place so many times I can't even count but I checked it out on the suggestion of some yelpers. My friend (a gal who also turns out to be a powerful singer) and I walked in just to see what was going on. I was a bit dismayed at first because it was empty but we asked to see their song book.   Wow! They have an up-to-date selection. The cool barkeep and cute waitress spoke BOTH Japanese and English so I flipped back and forth with them all night.  They had such classes as "yume no naka", and "Space battleship Yamato" and a few others.  The crowd that showed up later was quite mixed in age and race and remarkably supportive. Totally a bomb place to do duets, so make sure you bring a friend!

HbERm3eEVFAveflAJU-dxQ.review_text: This place is all about community -- it's basically San Francisco's "Cheers" -- just where everyone is singing and even the most aloof manly-man warms up with lychee martinis.   I've been coming to Festa for more than a year, and it only gets better and better for me and my friends who come one or two times a month. The bartenders are exceptionally nice, (Ken, Shogo, Satoshi) and Masae-san the owner treats us like family. We feel like family to them because this place is so small -- they make an effort to get to know their customers, but also it's part of their business: they depend on their customers to become regulars and support their bar. I've brought more than 30 different friends here over the past year and everyone leaves craving another go; it's just hard not to fall in love with the support always ready for the singer, the service always ready to ensure you have a great time.  I think any of the disgruntled Yelps on this place haven't given it enough of a chance or don't fully understand how hard it must be to crowd control this place given it's so small -- it can get really rowdy in there, people start screaming into the microphone, get so drunk they break glasses or tip over tables, and because they do have a reservation policy for larger groups, sometimes you do have to move for folks who've paid an extra cover.  I agree with a lot of the Festa regulars who've said it's even better on a weeknight; part of the "Cheers"-like draw. There have been many a work conflict or a friend disagreement thawed out by the incredibly fun and hilarious environment. I've never walked out of the bar without someone's email address for future karaoke nights. Also, you get to sing more often as fewer people are in the bar, and this has been the best time to bring people nervous to sing. Interestingly, every single person who's ever been to Festa with me who was intimidated by the Festa stage upon walking in never wanted to leave it after their debut song.  It's just an awesome discovery in a town where going out at night can be frosty, unfamiliar and too much of a scene.  None of that here. I hesitate to profess my love for Festa because I'm afraid it will become even more popular. But my love for this place (and appreciation given how great they've been to me and my friends) is the reason why I'm shouting from the rooftops.   Go. Have fun. It's great.

jBa1tIHKkVyVPS-l-KQ4Ww.review_text: Ok. So let me say.. I have loved this place for years. I have had many great experiences and spent A TON OF MONEY here over the years.. They normally have a great staff that is super friendly and generally attract amazing guests.. But last night was EPICALLY bad terrible customer service and I have been in the service industry for over 10 years so I'm not just being a bitch.. The kj last night not only was rude and dismissive but he basically told our friend that if she came outside and had a cigarette with him then he "might play our songs". Are you seriously blackmailing us after we paid for songs to be played? Not only do you owe us our money back for purposely not playing our songs but you are never getting a single dollar from us again. and I'll be telling all our karaoke loving friends to never come here again.

4DrYldibe6ziPkwbU5NSOg.review_text: I love love loooove their martini cocktails! I'd go there just for their saketini (w/premium sake)  Plus, you get to watch people singing while drinking. Free entertainment show :)  Welcoming bartenders, nice decor, and nice location. Definitely should check out.

IrT4wZj9Oc8595VgiAGfFA.review_text: Went here with a couple of former colleages from Japan here on a business trip. We got here early on a Saturday night ~7.30pm. The place was almost empty, just a couple of others. We got in about 6 songs each before it filled up quickly at around 9pm. This place is small so it fills up fast and you won't be singing many songs after that. Sound system was definately sub-par though compared to what I'm used to (7bamboo in San Jose Japantown is way superior). Mikes are sub-standard and they had the echo up way too high. Also, music level was often much too high, drowning out the singers voice. I had to ask the barman to turn down the music on some of my more quieter numbers. Place seems pretty friendly, staff OK. Can't comment on the cost as my Japanese colleagues paid but $2/song isn't too unreasonable I guess for Japantown. (7Bamboo in SJ charges $1 for a song). They had a huge collection of Japanese songs which was great.

KUIv4oJcC2zKT1uiqURqHw.review_text: I cannot say that this place is the worst establishment that I've ever been to however it's close to it.   I just went here tonight.  The place is really small and there is about 6 tables total in addition to the 6 or 8 stools at the bar area.  There were two-three bartenders working.  I arrived there at 10PM to meet with my party of seven people and it was really mellow and a little bit dead.  Around 10:30PM, people started to sing and once they started, the ball started to roll.  I've never done public karaoke before, so I ordered some Lychee Martini's to loosen me up :)  It was quite tasty and the bartenders were very fast in delivery and attentive as well; they came around a few times to check on each table.  The negative is each drink cost $9.00.  There was a huge binder of songs, which was pretty cool --oldies to current pop/rock.    I thought I'd actually be much more nervous on stage but I wasn't.  You come here expecting that people do not sing very well --it's not American Idol.  The people that I've met and witnessed tonight have all been really cool and friendly --very supportive and interactive with you when you are stumbling upon lost words.  I was actually singing a song that I have never heard and I got so much support from the crowd :)  They are very encouraging but in a non-pressuring kind of way --good folks.   Things were good until the owner started to move people around.  My group and I were asked to scoot in and squeeze together so that another group of people can sit down. This also happened to another table that was nearby us; there was an empty table where no one was sitting and the owner of the establishment had asked them to move from one table to the one where no one was sitting.  In addition to that, she took my drink away without asking if I was done with it.    Keep in mind that we've been there for over an hour or two and we were drinking and singing actively on stage.  I thought what she did was extremely rude --the rest of my party agreed so we left.  To make matters worse, we went to close our bill and found out that they had charged us for three additional drinks when we paid for them already in cash.  We tried resolving the issue by speaking to them and they refused to take the amount off.   Our night turned sour very quickly -- we will definitely never come back to this place again.  Also, I saw the cheese plate from another table and I definitely would not recommend ordering that.  It was literally slices of over priced cheddar or cheap looking cheese.  I am not impressed at all.

siuckubgSMp1DF3xNgZB1Q.review_text: I really wanted to like this place, especially after reading some good reviews about it.  I will NEVER return here.  Money grubbery - It is WAY too expensive.  My friend just had her birthday party there (weekend night) - they charged her a $10/person cover charge, my drink was $8 for a well drink, and then on top of that it was $2 PER song.  Then when she wanted to pull out her cake, they wanted to charge her an additional $20 to serve it.  So for 16 of us at the party to sing a song each (and have a SINGLE drink) it was $320!  You can get bottle service (including entry) at a shwanky night club for much less than that price.  Disorganization - On top of that they are incredibly disorganized with the karaoke.  Unlike other bars, which request people write their own names down on an organized song request form, this place hands you a blank piece of paper and no one writes their own name down.  When you hand it back to them, they put it in a disorganized pile of paper.  I put in my paper upon arrival at 9p and by 11p still it had not been entered in the machine (it shows the waitlist).  My friend paid for 20 songs for her party and had only used about 2-3 of them when I left - while the table next to us had one girl who went up three songs back to back.  Their complete lack of organization means a lot of the same people end up singing multiple times, and other people never get to go - all the while paying $2/song!  Other bars will usually let "new" people get priority to be more equitable.  Quality of atmosphere/service -  1.  Bartenders both bartend and KJ which means they are overwhelmed (explaining the disorganization) but it means it takes a while to get a drink or submit a song.  They should delegate one person to KJ only. 2. The microphones are awful!  Granted it's a karaoke bar not a music studio or anything, but these are perhaps the worst I've ever heard. 3.  One redeeming quality is that the bar itself has beautiful lighting and wood paneling, and it is a small intimate environment like other reviewers say. 4.  They do have a large song selection - which is also a plus.  I strongly recommend against this place.  I usually only write yelp reviews when I love or hate a place.  I think it is not worth the money.  There are too many other great places in SF.   If you're reading this from the restaurant, I've offered constructive concrete changes that could improve your place of business.

VixWUwYtTBrXSiS-JAfGow.review_text: This is a great local place to have fun!  I went there last night and it was consistent with the previous times I've been....tons of fun, great vibe and energy, the wine and cocktails were great (yes, I sing better after knocking back a couple), and the service was fantastic.  Plus, it's a perfect place to meet  a bunch of friends to sing your hearts away!

CxRRtAs6F5roJ9z18tfw8g.review_text: I have had some legendary evenings at this place, but the last time I went I left rather disappointed.  A friend and I wanted to go in for a drink and a song (drink for her, song for me for her =).  We sat down at the bar, were greeted immediately and given an English karaoke book.  My friend comes for the Lychee martini (with SKYY) which I have to admit, is a silent killer.  Delicious.  I had... regrettably... a five dollar bottle of Crystal Geyser.  I wish I'd have paid attention to the menu, but keep in mind, I did ask for a "glass of water, please."  Apparently, they do not offer water to their patrons.  The prices of drinks at Festa are astronomical, and there have been times where I felt like the large Sapporo was half water, but it all seemed tolerable when drunk and singing songs of joy and friendship.  It would have helped had either of the bartenders there cut us some slack and let us sing a song for the one dollar we had left after closing out our tab.  There's a ten dollar minimum for credit/debit card usage, and we weren't going to sit there and belt out five songs, so we had to accept the fact that rules is rules and sit there and listen to yet another rendition of Sweet Child o' Mine and the murder of All You Need is Love, while I tried desperately to convince myself I was drinking the best water on the planet.  "Now I gotta know what five dollar Crystal Geyser tastes like."  Festa... I love you and I will return, but man... I'll never order water again.

aYJHYl5zvQ73u82AlwGlBg.review_text: "There is NO WAY I am singing!  I am SO scared!"  45 minuets later...  "Honey, this is your 6th song in a row, would you please get off the stage?"   What can I say?  Cute, cozy, inviting place + Sake + Sake + Sake + Sake = me singing in Japanese without speaking a word of it; going on stage JUST to dance; and going back this Friday to do it all over again.

6veSoRwdfGBjxigxV91BsQ.review_text: Very cool and friendly karoake bar in Japantown.  You have to look to find it.  Lots of locals, a full bar, and huge encyclopedia of music.  A very United Nations crowd.  It doesn't look like much, but just hanging out for a few minutes and you feel like you are with a group of your closest friends in Tokyo.

ACUVZ4SiN0gni7dzVDm9EQ.review_text: When everything else closes up shop in the Kinokuniya building Festa is ready to party. My favorite part of this karaoke experience is that it's run by the bartenders. And they don't make any announcements about it being your turn to sing. They just keep the songs coming one after another and you have to listen for the one you submitted. When you hear it you run up to the stage and hope you make it to the mic before the words start. So if you like singing karaoke kamikaze-style in a place that's no bigger than most living rooms then get your vocal cords over to this spot stat.

-mbArZZDfAL1vjRA7YRjgw.review_text: Intimate. And nothing beats watching your friends make complete fools of themselves after taking a few of Fernet- Branca.

wm_8WajM1ByByrF1di3tKQ.review_text: Thanksgiving night worst customer service ever. Great customers celebrating a birthday party but the guy in charge of songs apparently thinks American idol missed him on their great search for talent. He's an arrogant "kj" who thinks he's going to be the next great thing and has no respect for his customers at Festa. Your loss.

lLfcbYGTeVxQN5Ig0ompJg.review_text: Review #700 goes out to Festa! I don't know why, but it's seems very fitting that my first time here was with the Duke of Festa, Bobby L. He sure knows how to karaoke! Lol!  Located in the Japantown mall, it's a small bar with a karaoke stage. I've been to a couple bars with a public karaoke stage, but most of my karaoke experience in Japantown has been in private rooms, so this was a little new for me. I'm not much of a singer, but I love cheering on my friends!  We came by last Thursday and it was busy, but we managed to find a table shortly after we got there. A couple drinks, some karaoke songs, more drinks and even more karaoke songs and suddenly it was last call! Has it really been 3 hours already?! I guess I didn't notice since I was having so much fun!  The staff and bartenders are super nice and the atmosphere is very homey and cozy. Even though I'm used to private karaoke rooms, Festa has changed my mind about karaoke bars. You can have fun singing in front of strangers too! Well for me, cheering on friends in front of strangers! Lol!

E1p1QZj9sYDkoWLnIX-qsA.review_text: a fun place but don't take it too seriously   on NYE table service was a bit slow but so what, we went to the bar and got drinks  the crowd was fun and the place had a cool vibe!

CDtbuyJBYyDT21lJMod6OA.review_text: This place is still fun, still wonderful, still magical...  But seriously people, if you can't afford it, DON'T COME HERE. Don't bring 20 people for a birthday party and expect VIP service when you DIDN'T make a reservation, DIDN'T know about the cake charge (this place is CARPETED so yeah, spills of outside food not acceptable), and DIDN'T see the 18% gratuity charge.  DUH.  I was in here on a date, hanging out with the bf in the corner, when a giant group came in under the above circumstances.  They didn't just attempt to sneak their cake twice, but they didn't clap or cheer for ANY OTHER customer singing, one girl was even literally rolling her eyes through an entire song that wasn't her friends'.  Can you believe how rude that is when Festa's atmosphere is so intimate and friendly???  I was overhearing them argue about the cake stuff with the bartenders... sheesh!   So yeah, Festa is a good time... but if you can't afford it, tough for you.  Don't come here!  Because you will end up complaining when it's really not Festa's fault.

xqe8QcpRryKuK2wn5TZJYg.review_text: After throwing a birthday party here for my boyfriend (nothing says love like public humiliation on a stage), I was horrified when I scrolled through my flipcam the morning after to see myself singing awkward renditions the likes of Johnny Cash, New Kids on the Block, and Olivia Newton-John.  Holy crap.  What happened that night?  Though I'm embarrassed to say I was only lucid for half the night, apparently that is the very essence of a really good time.  It seemed everyone else either didn't care, or rode the same shameless, tone-deaf bus that I did.  Needless to say, the drinks are strong.  REAL strong.  Pretty cool bartending crew.  I had reserved for a party of 12, so I had to pay about $10/head, PLUS 18% gratuity.  It's a bit steep for a kareoke bar, but given how packed it was, we were happy to have the prime real estate with a big table in the back.  By the end of the night, somehow an extra $34 got tacked onto the bill.  I'm pretty sure the final check was somewhere around $199 which already included gratuity.  That means, I had to have gotten out my little blackberry calculator and figure out 18% of $199 (the $34) - all in my totally inebriated state.  I don't remember doing it and was pretty unhappy to find that extra charge on my credit card a week later.  Now, the next part is what really made me like Festa - I called and left a message asking for a copy of the signed receipt. Masae, the manager who was out of town the day of my party, called me back personally to go over the charges.  We're still not clear on what happened that night.  Given my utter blackout, it's very possible I just made a mistake.  But she was happy to send me a credit for the extra amount to use the next time I went in - even though she said that amount probably went home with the bartenders and not to the bar.  And because of this I will definitely be going back.

Qfjh51erKvZi_dODWg_7Yw.review_text: OK, so I understand that SF has more than its share of overpriced hole-in-the-walls. I can accept that. As Festa is located in Japantown I had the feeling that their financial strategy was to cater to out-of-towners wanting some karaoke action in the city.  That's all fine and good, what I cannot accept is charging $8 for Doritos and trying to double tip trickery.  If you are charging $8 for guacamole and chips, and you cannot serve Doritos. I'm pretty sure there's a law against it. Now, don't get me wrong. I love Doritos, but I love them when I pay 99 cents a bag, not a $8 dollars. The second offense was more serious though.   When I went to pay the bill, my credit card had been charged a little more than I had expected. There was still the tipping space left blank so I assumed that maybe another item had been added to my bill. Low and behold, they had an 18% tip added because we were part of a group. The waitress explained this fact after the matter and pointed to a dark corner where there was 12-point font that explained their policy. OK, that's fine that that's your policy, what is not ok, is trying to get a double tip by presenting a receipt where there is a blank spot for the tipping section, and not mentioning that you've already received tip.   Service was terrible anyway, which makes that 18% tip all the more ridiculous.

_don8EWxNsvRdjDJqWbw0w.review_text: Came on a Wednesday night fairly early, which meant basically having the place to ourselves. Cute little karaoke bar. I have never in my life had to pay $2 per song at a karaoke bar. I can see how having to pay per song would limit the number of songs people would sing on a busy night, but if we are the only two people in your bar, is it really necessary for us to pay?  The drink menu was on point, but the appetizers we ordered were not. Edamame was soggy and watery and gaucamole out of a container and stale chips....YUCK.   $22 to sing 4 songs, have one glass of wine and eat some soggy edamame.

skar1XyXyjTKKUawy-NlyA.review_text: It's been awhile since I've actually gone to any other Karaoke place because my friends LOVE LOVE LOVE Festa, so I almost can't compare.    First off, I almost always have a super fun time.    Second, it's a lounge, not private rooms, so it's definitely the place to go if you either a) want to sing in front of a room full of strangers, or b) you are with just one or two others and it would be a little weird to book a private room elsewhere in Japantown.    Third, it's pretty cozy, and the drinks are pretty good (both wine and cocktails, like lychee martini).  I also like the city skyline background when you sing, as it makes for great photos!    Finally, they do a decent job of taking your requests and rotating between different tables to make sure different groups get a turn.  (Of course the negative side of this is that if you have multiple people in your group, it can take awhile for you to get to sing).    But it's a decently up to date song list (not the most current songs though),  $2 a song, and about $10 a drink.  For a few hours of entertainment it cost us $25 apiece so that seems okay.  The crowd definitely ebbs and flows - you have your regulars who sing Frank Sinatra and other oldies - but as always, the fun quotient depends on who else is there too.  It definitely gets more crowded sometime around 11 pm, and then it can be standing room only.   The only other thing I'll note is that it's in Japan Center, and it can take awhile to navigate between those buildings!

CLn96S95pDqWGkgTZS2AnA.review_text: Tiny fun karaoke lounge not full of boisterous drunks.

ODSH1it5oAUPu2clIgOvyg.review_text: The first time you walk in here, you might think it's pretty darn small and will be too cozy with the rest of the audience. I mean, we don't go to a karaoke bar to show off our singing skills and perhaps dancing talents. No, we come here to have a good time, laugh about our tone deafness, and share our drunken embarrassment on stage in front of strangers, who are also doing the same.  It's pretty inmate here, I wish it was bigger or that they'd expand it a little. The bar area could be minimized to increase the efficiency. The same could be said about the narrow hallway as well. What's really funny is that the sound of the place could be projected out onto the streets, and delight people passing by.  Drinks weren't cheap, and the bartenders had a hard time keeping track of who bought which drinks, so our tabs were mixed up pretty well at the end of the night. They have every single song you can think of. The stage is tiny as well, but we managed to fit 8 people up there, although it was a very tight squeeze. They charge for each song that you sing, which is a first for me at a karaoke place. You mean I have to PAY to humiliate myself for other people's entertainment? I guess it's to limit people from singing too much  Pretty cool place to come and hang out at.

XHuNSjrPA3Vyi7n4iVhZaQ.review_text: If men didn't find me repulsive (and trust me, the feeling is mutual), this is the kind of place I would go on a date. It's tucked into Japantown and you feel as if you are in Tokyo, or the kind of place I imagine Tokyo to be: excessively priced drinks (9 dollars for a gin and tonic!? what am I, in Vegas?) and a fake skyline everywhere, with drunk old men trying to cop a feel on my hot friends.   Anyway, as a place to do karaoke, Festa is just okay. They charge per song (inexcusable, especially since there is no KJ) and this is the kind of place you will hear 8,000 renditions of Sweet Caroline in one night.   However, as a place to close out the night and ogle a cute bartender, it gets 4 shining stars.

emF8KqAfI2VL6Sfaek9gFg.review_text: Have you ever waltzed into a karaoke bar and immediately graced the stage with one of your favorite songs without even having to request it? It's the way to go, folks. And I speak from my experience at Festa!  We had just done room-style karaoke at a random sketchy place a little further down Fillmore. The lack of English selection there was just not cutting it for us, so we peaced out after an hour in search of something else in the area. Walking on Post, I saw the sign for Festa, and remembered my cousin had always raved about that place. We decided to hop into Japantown to check it out.  The minute we walked in, I randomly saw my supercool friend Jason C. on stage singing with a drunk dude and instantly knew it was gonna be a good night. He saw me just as the next song he requested--Total Eclipse of the Heart, one of my go-tos--was coming on, and called me up to sing with him. So I did! Ain't no thang. The crowd loved it... just sayin'. That's how I roll at karaoke.  But seriously. This spot has officially won me over as my favorite karaoke bar in SF. It's a bit smaller than the other ones I've been to, but as a result there are less people and you have more chances to sing. I think the size also makes it's impossible for you to have left the bar without making new friends (maybe it was just the night I went, but the crowd vibe here is super fun). There's also a full bar with the friendliest people ever serving you huge Sapporo beers ($10). The twinkling city skyline backdrop on the stage is not as cheesy as it sounds and only adds to the magic.  And of course, you never know who you'll run into here. Shoutout to my buddy Jason C. Til we sing together again ;). Festa forever!

QPGP_UNEkzrWPPyWeUZv2Q.review_text: Festa rocks my world.  This is the place I come to a few times a month to knock a few drinks back and sing my heart out. After a long week at work there isn't a better way to unwind and decompress.   The intimate, friendly atmosphere is what makes this place tops. The crowd here is fun and supportive so even if you're a little scared to sing up on stage alone, everyone else will be singing along with you anyway. :) It's also nice to come to a karaoke bar where you don't have to deal with rude karaoke DJ's or wait around for 3 hours to never hear your song come on. Plus, their pomegranate martinis are yummy and potent.  Some people are complaining about the $2/song fee. If you're complaining about spending $2 then you should head over to your nearest seedy dive bar instead of coming to a place with a nice ambiance.

0WcUP0kdhdx4A-L9d7mHgw.review_text: Um why haven't I ever known about this place before???  Yeah, hello.  I'm ashamed for being a native and not knowing about this cute, tidy, little place where I would not be ashamed to take people to.  My cousin knew about this place and he took me and our other cousin visiting from NYC and I was like "where the hell are we going?"  And low and behold a little bar where like one couple was drinking at the bar and chatting with a sweet waiter.  But I also felt like only early-bird special citizens would be kicking it here but none were in sight.  We ordered drinks and because only the couple and the waiter were singing I mustered up some courage and sang a song.  Then like 15 minutes later 2 huge groups of white people came in and started singing and drinking.  I was like "how did they know about this place?"  They must have Yelped it.  LOL.

deMySa63_mE3Jy2lWMU1Dg.review_text: So we spent around 50 bucks at a table for drinks and songs. I go outside for a call and see a  vending machine. I buy an awesome grape drink with REAL GRAPES in it. I bring it in. I wasn't trying to sneak it in or anything. It was a spur of the moment buy cause I was a bit tipsy. And these grape drinks are awesome.   The owner comes up to our table and tells me no outside drinks. The owner knows my friend is a regular, and still doesn't let her rule slide, so I just leave.  I give them one star for them having  "great" business sense!  Never coming back here again.

kK996Gx3ZoR7Avd5WILFEg.review_text: What do you say about a Karaoke bar the size of a doctor's office waiting room that has lots of asian pop and at least one Children of Bodom song in its songbook, and a bartender with sideburns that extend down onto his neck (Does this count as a neckbeard? why are there no web pages mocking this?) and six dollar bottles of sapporo?  If you think of something, let me know. I'm drawing a blank for this review.

5h4F3RxA2qLLm3wdTjcbtQ.review_text: Fun atmosphere and great drinks. Gets crowded on the weekend but everyone is very cool so come early grab a drink and a seat and enjoy!

oi8bxWg-Pxj4W8mV7rN6EA.review_text: This is one of my favorite bars. The staff is friendly, the stage is intimate, and the Sapporo is served ice cold in chilled glasses, the way it should be. On top of that, there is an immense song selection (just be sure to look in multiple books) and it has carpet. Carpet? Are you kidding me?   Where else will you find a clean, carpeted bar?   Oh, and if you're lucky, you might see a local celebrity or two. This is the kind of place where you'll never run into anyone you know...unless they're on the up-and-up with secret karaoke bars in malls ;)

rrOqDzMFTvpJ4akcIYuGTQ.review_text: I have never reviewed an establishment for yelp but I feel compelled to after last night.   I went there with a few friends for a quick drink and some entertainment. When the server came over, I ordered a shot of whiskey and a coke chaser.... When the bill came, I was charged $9 for the shot and $5 for the coke chaser. That makes a $14 whiskey and coke! I asked the server if something was wrong and he looked at me like I was crazy... Never going there again.

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: You want to go karaoke, but you don't want to rent a room and you don't want to go to a big place that has a hundred people all trying to sing.   Festa to the rescue.  The drinks aren't cheap and the songs are $2, but that's good cause who wants to spend more than an hour in a karaoke place anyway?

NLvNv-Au5Jldu84CubsoEw.review_text: This much is "True"- Festa is "La Isla Bonita" for you and your folks after a long day of working "9 to 5". "I Swear" if you can get Festa all to yourselves, the stage is "Open Arms". Otherwise, when there are other parties that are filled with mic hogs, you're "Living on a Prayer" and Festa just becomes a plain ol' bar. The service is attentive and friendly even for the "Dancing Queens". The faux skyline backdrop on stage makes you "Hip to Be Square". (PS- apologies for the lame karaoke-ish review.)

nGozHYFspeWe2DliD9GqcA.review_text: This place is perfect for those of you who: think you hate karaoking (I know, can you believe those people exist??), have never gone karaoking or think you're "tired" of the sport.  I always ask myself why I don't come here more often. It has all the qualities of a great night: amazing bar and bartenders, easy (FREE) street parking after 8 pm, several hundred songs to choose from AND those classy Asian karaoke music videos playing in the background. There is absolutely nothing more I could ask for.  Festa is such a local joint. If someone snaps a picture of you singing in front of the fake skyline onstage or merrymaking with some pals in those obnoxious red swivel seats, only locals would know where you are. I love that about Festa. Plus the door guy is cute so don't forget to chop it up with him.   I suggest coming in March during the SF Asian American International Film Fest to watch all of the festival staff unleash their inner Mariahs and Left Eyes (90s reference).

SaHQtjBdJtbjQBdq80cRMg.review_text: When I rolled up to Festa late on a Tuesday night and the entire shopping mall was deserted less a tiny bar full of people jammin' karaoke, I had no idea what type of fun awaited me.  I'm no stranger to a karaoke night. I have hit many a bar in search of a mike and some cheesy 80's music. But this one is different. It's tiny and there's no formal announcement when it's your song. You just hear the music and take the stage. It was fantastic.   Drinks were pouring. Ice cold beer and tasty cocktails all around. And there may have been a shot or two once or twice. All great and pretty easy on the wallet.   Recommend!

xH4xGSXYrctie4dHZNdflw.review_text: If there was a way to not give this place any stars I would.  It started out okay and fun was to be had by all.  But then things quickly turned around...the owner forced us to move from our long established seats in order to make room for the already crowded room.  Then if things couldn't get worse, they double charged us for three drinks and refused to fix it.  Never, ever, ever again will I enter this place.  Never.

PBmotLhDczArA10xRJ-_5w.review_text: BRING YOUR CAPE AND BOOTS.   This is an old school karaoke bar. You'll see the hot middle aged Japanese women tending bar and the creepy old white guys who seem nice enough but are just a little too touchy by Asian standards. Good song selection and plenty of high kick room on stage. Make a fool of yourself in front of others, there's no feeling quite like it.

WB-ivH1N3Jew0oFs98NqYQ.review_text: La la la la laaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.... *glass breaks from the high pitched screeches*  When I think of a karaoke place, I think of those Korean owned places with individual rooms. There are endless booklets of English, Korean, Chinese and Japanese songs to choose from. And ALL the music videos have absolutely nothing to do with the song it's played with.   Well, this is definitely NOT that kind of karaoke place.  This is an OPEN MIC karaoke place. Brave souls (or just really drunk people) can sign up to sing whatever song they want to the entire bar. I can see where the appeal is after you've hammered a few drinks. They may be loud and out of tune, but they're definitely having fun!  The bar itself is tiny and located inside the Kinokuniya building in Japantown. It's shoved in a little corner on the second level. If you have a hard time finding the place, just listen for the faint yet amplified screams of tone-deafness.   It may be small, but it's a full bar inside! They even have soju and sake by the bottle!   With a great selection of alcohol and the endless volunteers for karaoke, you can be entertained for hours! And if you can't stand the sound, take a breather in the hallway or down another drink. =P

BRh5hZvTU-xYXux5WnjBMQ.review_text: Seriously.  I'm a HUGE fan of the Mint.  It's my go-to place.  However, sometimes it's crowded.  Sometimes, the talent is pretty amazing.  Sometimes, it's a s***show.  Regardless, karaoke is in my blood and needs to sing.  I was having an early dinner at State Bird Provisions (see that review too!) with some periphery friends.  I'm just getting to know these folks and dinner was great for conversation only to discover a mutual love of the karaoke.  They mentioned that Festa is their fave place and right around the corner.  Epic.  The place was empty on a Saturday at 6:30.  We sang 9 songs before the next people came in.  When they did, so did everyone else, but that hour almost of just us and the drinks and the stage and the decor and everything.  It was pretty great.    While I hate to yelp about this for fear of other folks finding it, I still think you need to experience it.  I'm likely not due for another karaoke adventure until July, so have at it until then and maybe you'll hear my mean "Careless Whisper" like a siren song luring you there.

S34qI4Jvdn-Nn5rfuKzgYw.review_text: Leave your dignity at door.  This is the effing real deal, the Karaoke BAR.  None of that bullshit booths with people humming along...  It's just you and the strangers.  There is an intense correlation between utter excitement and the anticipation of being possibly humiliated.  The latter usually breeds the excitement, I think.  But ultimately the environment at Festa is more than friendly, as long as you're drinking.    And be warned: Sweet Caroline is the herpes of Karaoke song.  You'll be guaranteed to hear it for days, annoyed, yet incapable of getting rid of it.

v27Rcd0iqJNvIQ_3gtaD4A.review_text: "So I put my hands up, they're playing my song..." YEP. My friends and I sang Miley Cyrus and so much more.  Our large group came here on a Friday after dinner together and found this to be one of the better places to spend the rest of our night. There were so many music choices and all different types of people in here. My white friends were so shocked to find other white people who were able to sing in Japanese and Chinese - they were confused. REALLY CONFUSED. It was great!   My friend really wanted to come here because as a frequent customer, she loves hearing one of the bartenders sing and HE WAS REALLY GOOD!   PLEASE - for the sake of everyone else. If you ever come here, sing an upbeat song. You should only be allowed to sing a depressing song IF you are amazingly good and have soul. Otherwise, spare us - we're all trying to have a fun time!   Overall, I think everyone had a great time. Great for large groups of people, but not too large because it does get a little crowded. It started filling up around 9:30 p.m.   They also have lychee martinis here - YUM! Perks of asian-inspired bars...

KWqtFdvWPN4viYncgRANfA.review_text: BEST.PLACE.EVER.  I'm not a lover of karaoke, but I LOVE FESTA.  I usually refer to this place as SHOGO'S! (let's go to SHOGO'S!) because he's one of the bartenders (this chill Japanese guy who's in some punk Japanese band), and, for some reason, around the end of the night, we start yelling his name over and over again (SHOGOOOOO!! SHOGOOOOO!).  Usually, it's while we're trying to shove a shot down his throat.  Whatevs.    Anyways, it's a small, kinda cheesy room with a bar, some seating, and a stage - none of this private room crap.  Song selection is pretty good (Japanese, Mandarin, Cantonese, prob Korean and of course, English) and they're pretty current.  People who frequent the place appreciate good singing but appreciate it even more if you just lay it all out there on stage.  Just belt it, who freaking cares if you're not an awesome singer and don't know all the words?!  EVERYONE ELSE THERE SINGS WITH YOU!  EVEN IF IT'S IN A LANGUAGE THEY DON'T KNOW!!  It's like one big happy family!  You may not get all the songs you put in, but that doesn't mean you can't sing along with everyone else's!    Not for those looking for a quiet place to sing every song they know.  Cuz it ain't gonna happen.  At least on Fridays and Saturdays.  Only thing is drinks are on the pricier side so a little pre-partying wouldn't hurt.

DvVj-bD8-ccNW1m7zCO7WA.review_text: Best karaoke bar in SF.  Great selection, real track music or at least close to it (not that crap muzak they use at Nap's).  Unquestionably worth the $2/song.  My performances last week: "Dreams" by Van Halen (ie: Van Hagar) "Just Like Paradise" by David Lee Roth "Goin' Back to Cali" by Notorious B.I.G. "Mr. Roboto" by Styx  ...plus some more that I can't recall right now.  I need to hang out in Japantown more often.

LeKErORR7n1_Z4WeWxhWHA.review_text: As a previous Festa fan of four years, I'm truly disheartened by the fact that the bartenders hassled my party to buy drinks not even 10 minutes upon arrival. Also hassled again when a new comer came in to check it out and just say hello to us- we were still working on a large sake. For some reason they SHORTENED happy hour to 1 hour (okkkk?). They advertise happy hour for 2 hours when in actuality it's one hour from 8-9pm and by 8:30pm they will charge $2/song for the simple reason that by the time your song gets played it would be past 9pm. Now no one is saying that $2/song is too much for karaoke but when you're friends are being told to, "not make a big deal about it" it really sends a tactless message to new patrons. I talk this place up all the time but truly- it seems to be turning into a sham of a nightlife establishment. It is so unfortunate to us veterans to know that a gem like Festa is going down hill from here. We ended up paying just as much for a private room at DoReMi karaoke studio down the street and had an epic time!

fjhiDNGbrSfzfDxWbWgimA.review_text: To view the entire review, check out my blog (link in my profile)  What an absolute blast! Nice ambiance, a welcoming vibe (especially for a trembling first time karaoke singer like myself), nice drink selection and awesome bartenders!   Atsuko, one of the bartenders, was so friendly made us feel right at home. Service was quick even as the place started to heat up. And you didn't have to wait all night before your song came up like some places I've been in LA.  Bravo! I'll definitely be back!

IqZGTaY2zNP5CT0xY6JsBQ.review_text: The only way a karaoke bar can beat Festa is if the Bon Jovi, Guns 'N Roses, and Elton John songs are actually being sung by Bon Jovi, Axl Rose, and Sir Elton John.  Don't let the unassuming entrance and small size fool you, as this intimate bar packs a serious punch.

JADdo9NEeO5Az9aOYbyvZA.review_text: ********************* 1225 **********************      A cool karaoke place inside the Japan Town, tiny, and it was jam packed at 9:30 PM on a FRI night. A few tables, a small bar with less than 8 seats. Limited wines and cocktail list.      Capacity can not be more than 30 people.  I counted 40+ at the time I was there. I came in for a quick drink. They substituted the wine I ordered. I guess no one drink wine on a weekend night but me! Somm problem, ehhh!      The white bartender was nice and cute. Nice owner too, she remembers my friend. People were signing, laughing, and having a great time. Service was nice and fast. Just got into the bar to order your drinks was a struggle because it's too packed. I got a seat at the bar, and I got a few girls pushed me and knocked their giant handbags over me. I guess this is why I rarely go out anymore :-)     If you like me, like a personal space, this is NOT for you. If you like to smell other people sweat and people screaming at your face. You would fit right in here. It's definitely a cool joint if you are into karaoke with a group of friends.

Q9nLBFOUMpEfAUU_lncZpQ.review_text: This is the funnest place. Yes, the drinks are pretty expensive, but it's just the cost of night life. I just wish there were more people who went there to sing who weren't so good. Everyone seemed to sing pretty good. Oh well, I still didn't mind singing badly. Yay. Oh, the song book was great, BUT, my only problem with it was it's organization was confusing. You could sit there for hours looking for stuff. Other than that minor issue, this place is a blast!

lUfLgIjISLFmWbJNkkqNxQ.review_text: One of my favorite spots!  They are oh so very accommodating when let's say I get the urge to pop in and sing a song right before closing time.  Excellent customer service.  A fabulous selection of songs.  And the drinks and cocktails are super yum!  Who could ask for anything more really?   This might just be one of the Best karaoke spots in the Bay Area!

SjYund2wfZYp5M5VtuFtlA.review_text: Cool place, lots of people coming in for one or 2 drinks and belting out a favorite tune. There is a stage with 2 mics so if you are shy, you can invite a friend to sing with you. Staff and bartenders are friendly. Even if you are not a good singer, the crowd appreciates the effort.

1nu_dQuqLsRC8kP_CJCQsw.review_text: The place is a rip off vodka and a beer 17 dollars. Don't come here!!!!!!!

Szg--2wonu3BEdIav_vbCw.review_text: I'm reviewing this place as a place for a private Karaoke Event.  So I've had two friend's birthdays where they decided to Karaoke. One was at a regular Karaoke place and one was here. My friend rented out the entire room for some unknown amount of money. But it was worth it.  Unlike the regular asian places where there's no central point of look at everyone just looks at the screen, this is more how I thought karaoke should be. With one or two people singing the actual song in front and being able to put on a real performance.   The alcohol was decent and regularly priced, the service was excellent, and they had giant song books with pretty much every song known to man. There are of course exceptions (really no OffSpring?), but whatever. They also have far more modern stuff, this is the only place I've seen Lady Gaga in. They even had the latest Katy Perry song (the one that just came out from the date of this review).   One weird thing was that the books titles were mixed up. The one that was sorted by artist was sorted by title, the one by title was actually by artist. UPDATE: This was fixed, apparently the owner reads Yelp reviews, if only there was 6 stars?
