FgBx3WFYm7R-T_sSp2XK7g.review_text: this is a japanofile mecca!  you can get your drink on and sing till your heart's desire.  you may even be able to pickup a kogaru if you try hard enough.  on any given night you may be able to spot a group of salarymen here for business, singing britney spear's songs.  prepare to dish out some okane, and expect some nihon style prices.....they charge per song  other than that...this place is awesome!

ICwMfseYkrB0ZEK8tDUOHw.review_text: I would have never known this place if not for Tiffany N., who wrangled quite a few of us into this shopping mall for karaoke the other night.   The tiny lounge is nothing much to look at (unless you like fake cityscapes gracing the walls), but the atmosphere was super friendly with everybody cheering and singing along. The bartender was one of the smiliest people who ever lived too.   The bartenders do everything, so you pop them your song and two bucks (paying to sing is still pretty foreign to me, but I hear it's common in SF). Then, everyone stares at the screen after each song, braced to sprint up to the stage if they hear their song starting. This flustered me the first time since I didn't know (and missed like, three lines of my song before I made it up there). However, it's super efficient and it works well for them here!

dpEtyfB2o7MH1Mc_Ygoolg.review_text: Possibly the best karaoke bar in SF even though it's fairly unknown. Festa is all about the music. I saw some fantastic singers here. They were so good that I was embarrassed to go onstage. Eventually I worked up the courage to bust out a 10 minute performance of Rapper's Delight -- a song I haven't seen elsewhere.   The song selection at Festa is huge and bigger than any other place in SF I've been to. The friendly bartender kept the hot sake coming and I had a great time here.

lsSiIjAKVl-QRxKjRErBeg.review_text: Nice ambience and owner/bartender Ken is fun and down to earth. The other bartender doesn't speak english well....or at all? It took a while to explain/ask her if they had Level Vodka because she didn't understand me (it wasn't loud in the bar, there were only 3 other people aside from our group of 5).   I asked for Belvedere instead but she couldn't read the labels of vodka that was on the shelf. I kept telling her "the last one......the only one on the shelf that has the letter 'B'!). She went down the line, pointing at each and every bottle while asking me if that was Belvedere. Oy vey.....  The song selection was good and the sound system was decent. The only thing I didn't care for was the stage that you have to stand on to sing. Luckily for shy people like myself, Ken has 2 cordless mics set up in addition to the mics on the stage. I was able to sing from the comfort of our table.   Songs are $2 each but they do have a Karaoke Happy Hour that runs from Mon to Thurs, 7:30pm to 9pm. Just mention "yelp" to get in on that deal.

nwfojiMFQQJhNkR7vCCwyw.review_text: Festa is my favorite karaoke bar in SF. The cityscape backdrop is so cute! They have a great sound system, so you actually sound good and can hear yourself, unlike other places that have crappy mics and speakers. Pretty good song selection-they actually have two different books, so you might want to check them both if you're searching for a certain song. Ken, the bartender/server, always makes us feel welcome. The vibe is cozy and the crowd is friendly and supportive. Festa wa totemo subarashii, desu!

puS8HuNdeXhhl5F4bb0EEg.review_text: I dig karaoke...a lot!!!  But I had a very bad experience coming here.  So I came here with good friends of mine.  The place has good decor no doubt but $2 a song?  Come on now, really?  I wanted to have spent that money on drinks instead.  And there was a time where they were playing songs of people who requested after us and turns out they had put my paper at the bottom by mistake.  We had a little disagreement with some drunk girls who tried to steal our stage during our turn.  No respect at all.  If that wasn't irritating enough, the management didn't do anything about it.  Okay, one of my friends was a regular here.   And he's been bringing 4 or so people with him each time.  Where's the pay off for loyalty?  Apparently, they didn't care.  We left that place annoyed.  Too bad Festa, you lost one good customer, oh wait, make that 10 and some customers.

WUrP2e3c4UnfOvrZw9mpNw.review_text: I call this place "The Water-Hoarders" due to the surreal struggle i had getting a glass of precious hydration in this pace. I walked in with a group of about 8 friends around 11. The server asked me for my order first, and being that we had just walked about 15 blocks, I said I just wanted a "water for now." The waiter told me I had to order something else. I thought he might be joking, so I just stared at him. I told him I was going to order a drink in a bit, and he said "everybody lies and says that. You have to order your drink now or else i will charge you for the water." I turned to my friend and audibly requested that she order the controversial H2O on my behalf. She ordered a beer and a water, and when he brought back all the drinks for the table he shot me a dirty look and ceremoniously sat the water down RIGHT in front of my friend.  We all sang a bunch of songs and actually had a pretty good time (although I credit that to the musical stylings of my crew). We were not at all shocked to find that when our checks came we found mysterious and random charges. I asked why my $9 lychee martini (which was made with well vodka and was one of the worst I've had) came out at 12. The bartender told me "sometimes the owner adds a gratuity. If you have an issue you are going to need to take it up with her." The owner was glaring at our group (which brought in the bulk of their business that night and made friends with most of the other patrons) so I just paid and left. Even though I begrudgingly admit it is a fun environment, I will NEVER go here again and encourage you to find a place that does not bite the hand that feeds.

e1FuiYSV1v29q2OTR9ojBA.review_text: Who knew that J-town was totally happening on a Saturday night?    When we couldn't fit our entire party into the small karaoke room at Playground, a few of us drifted over to Festa, located near the Kinokuniya Bookstore in the Japan Center.    OMG.  THEY HAD KARAOKE THERE TOO, Y'ALL! (With a pretty damn good song list, including songs in Korean and Japanese.)  There weren't that many people when we got there, so we commandeered a few tables and a lot of chairs and ordered some drinks (a liiiiiittle on the pricey side, but it's near a hotel, so I guess that's somewhat understandable).  I did my best Mariah Carey impersonation and was warmly received by the enthusiastic audience.  As the night went on, more and more people came in and joined in the karaoke festivities.  Fun little spot, complete with swanky decor and illuminated cityscape backdrop on the karaoke stage.  It was fantastic, and I would most definitely go there again!

F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw.review_text: I've been to Festa numerous times and I must say that performing karaoke there is not for the shy folks.  But if you are one, it's a great way to conquer your shyness and just let loose and have fun.  It took A LOT of visits for me to finally have to courage to go up and sing.  Keep in mind, I am not a singer, but I enjoy singing tunes while I'm driving so this was a way to share some of my favorites to the audience at Festa.  Of course once you get used to being up on their stage, you get really comfortable and then actually want to belt out tunes on a whim.  If you're just starting out, I really recommend going Sunday-Wed when it's not as busy and you can get in more than one song.  The crowds are usually full of regulars during these times and they are really cool folks.  The song selections are pretty extensive and they get updated periodically.  I don't drink much alcohol but they do have a nice menu of wine, cocktails, and beer.  So it's a great spot to take a group of friends or family for some drinks and entertainment.  I really have to thank Bobby L. for introducing me to Festa.  It's become a great new hangout for me with a great atmosphere, cool people, and fun musical entertainment.

Pf1unbro2fH4lkd_9yfm3A.review_text: Wow! Ok years ago I used to come here...it was double the size and served shrimp treats...super cheese... Fast forward Now.....Much Much Better Cool intamate stage....Love the Background... I had a really Great Time here. The Bartendars were Very Friendly. Drinks are Pricey but that's exspected...I think its odd to charge $2.00 per song when people are paying 10.00 a pop for coctail s , I understand more when its slow...but one has to Pay to Play ...its all Good.... I had a Blast , the Cat's I ended up chatting with were so much fun and were such nice people.They come here alot, and geeze they had Amazing Voices...so so fun....I rarely get out...They were forsure the Big Bonusus to meet.Thanx so much for not laughing at me singing buck owens stuff....Im glad the guy from Texas moved here...R&B suits him well...Lol, fantastic Voice..... I was stopping in for one Cocktail after the Bathhouse and ended up staying until 2:00.... Im. Not sure about others but The Staff was very very friendly..singing was absolutely free until 9:00. Its 2014 get over yourself for complaining...shame on the Negitive reviewers.... Thanks japantown for keeping this place inside....keep laughing

MwMSwfSGVkebwH2FZaZybw.review_text: I found this place while visiting family during Thanksgiving break (Sister in law played a show at Yoshi's around the corner). The first time we walked in it was completely packed, so we hit another bar and came back at around 12:45a.m.   When we (party of 5) returned the place was about half full, yet it still took over 20 minutes before anyone approached our table (the guy at the front entrance). I asked him if I could order a drink from him, he went and got someone.   By now only half of us wanted to keep drinking. Our waiter told us it was a rule that each person had to order a drink. At this point our party kept looking at the menu.   Two songs were ordered at $2 each before the book was taken away from us because "we're just full." Another, delightfully smiley server came and asked us to order drinks- one per person. All but one of us ordered a beverage.   During one of our songs, another girl jumped on stage and stole the song.   When I was billed, I was arbitrarily charged $2 for not having everyone buy a drink at my table. I asked the server to charge me appropriately. He did, rudely. Then added a dollar in "sales tax." Not only is alcohol not supposed to have a sales tax unless you're in a restaurant, the tax was just not right.   I asked the server for his name and he replied, "I don't have to give you my name." Of course not. He was the only white server on the Friday after Thanksgiving with brown hair and some facial hair.   I love supporting small business because of the quality of service. I am an excellent tipper and say my please and thank yous. This place gave me the worst service in San Francisco during my 5 day visit.   If you value your time and money, support someone who does too.

re3AdczLFP4D7xwI6DkBNA.review_text: bathroom smelled like vomit but considering several individuals were over the limit on their libation intake made sense..   cute small venue  owner was super cool  TONS OF SONGS!

bG6DkJKwhKMMQ0Z3GSOpmA.review_text: When you're rolling to a karaoke joint with someone who considers the Art of Karaoke more of a Bloodsport than an Art, you know you're in for a good time.  I'd argue that the ambiance of Festa is worth the trek to Japantown alone. Then again, I was really drunk when we got there. There's really no excuse for the wallet-walloping drink costs & the $2/song request fee.  Seriously? You're CHARGING for each request? Aren't we supposed to just TIP really well so that you'll play them? They're really not down with Formalities here.  Still, a great time was had by all, & this is definitely the kind of bizarre place you will feel priviledged to close your night out at. Just make sure you save Guns N' Roses for the finale, because there's really no way you're going to be able to sing anything else after shredding your vocal chords on that Axl impression.

bxPYREtZeH98clXftApGhg.review_text: i'm surprised at all the rave reviews for this place.  the group i was with arrived to festa around 9:30pm or so.  the five of us camped out in the booth in the corner.  it was my first time.  man, what a small place... not in a bad way, just intimate and i never would have known this place existed.  i don't think it's divey at all like some of the other reviews said.  i've done divey and festa is not divey.  you can't call a place that charged $9 for a gin and tonic a dive bar.  speaking of $9 gin and tonics, i order a tanqueray and tonic and it was $9 and on my next drink i thought to specify that i wanted their well gin thinking it would be at least a few bucks cheaper... nope, $9.  i had three drinks and i could have taken that $30 and purchased myself a bottle of gin, tonic and limes and gotten myself sloppy drunk.  ANYWAYS...  i'm a huge fan of karaoke and was surprised to learn that you have to pay $2 to sing.  uh, come again?  and the guy who manages the karaoke thing told my friends that the song order is not done by who gets their songs in first but instead by table to limit repeats or something.  yeah, well, what we didn't know is that you can slip the karaoke guy some extra money to get your song bumped up to the top of the list.  we learned this when someone in our group had to wait like 45 minutes for their song.  seems like it could be a fun place... but over-charging for drinks, charging for karaoke, limited seating... no thanks.

Qrza-_Tu6MCBYZ4B1M06pQ.review_text: OK here's the date:   1) Sammy Hagar concert at the Fillmore   2) Pancho Villa Taqueria for tacos and beer   3) Festa Wine & Cocktail Lounge for Karaoke   Is this a weird date?!  YES, it really really is.  Was it awesome to be the first person to have to sing in front of a crowded room of blank faced Japanese men, YES, I seriously kick ass at Whitesnake songs so that was no problem.  Bizarre but cool that on said date we did not one but TWO (God I'm sure everyone was SOO sick of us) duets, one to summerlovin' (yes, we did that, everyone groan) and one to Patience by G n' R.  God, I mean really this was the most unconventional date in the history of the universe but also super duper fun.  This karaoke bar RULES.   Apparently the dating bar has been set, I can't really humiliate myself any more than I already have with this guy so the door is wide open.  Perhaps on the next date we will go to a mime class or improv, really the sky appears to be the limit.

Jt_GERujHtgp65YYN2c9gg.review_text: Tuesday night. Jtown is quiet. Eat sushi. Wander the empty halls. 9pm. Doorway seeps dark energy. Pulled in. Koji cleans glasses. Kim at usual spot. Three red wines. Nobody singing yet. Make that two wines, one Sapporo. Chatter in Japanese. Koji laughs. Nice to see you again. Green Day comes on. Remember last time? Yukiko pulls my arm. Do you have the time? To listen to me whine? Dance like Jagger. More Sapporo. Koji plays a Gibson SG. Older Japanese guy sings. Respectful lull. Devastatingly sad song. Applause. 11pm. Yukiko is a pilot? And a bartender? Sachiko is given the mike. I didn't know you could sing! You're a nightingale! Elvis has entered the building. Air guitar on Yukiko's leg. Kim loves Elvis. Harmonies on Lauryn Hill. Club soda, then more wine. 1am. Finger food. Promise you'll fly me to Vegas? I'll totally do it. Another sad song. Quiet. Old man has heart! AC-DC. Devil horns, rock faces. We salute you. Gulp down Sapporo. Goodbye, thanks. Come to my gig. I didn't know you could sing? Vegas, we're doing it. Stumble to cab. Daydream on the way home.

X7PUjszRgvM7fllXP3AwtA.review_text: We love Festa!  It's a small, fun Karaoke bar in Japantown.  Good Karaoke selection, the service is great and prices are reasonable.  And there's always a fun crowd.

ET8n-r7glWYqZhuR6GcdNw.review_text: Ben B said it best when he described Festa as "looking like an airport watering hole in Tulsa mixed with a stage borrowed from bad nineties stand up."  I couldn't describe the place better myself, and I won't try. Walking into this scene made me instantly melancholy and perhaps a little icked out, but I knew there was a bigger reason for my presence, and it wasn't the decor. Karaoke!  When I discovered the drink list and the option of a lychee martini, things were looking up considerably. Especially when the bartender humored my request to modify the recipe ever so slightly. My drink was fantastic, so I had two more.  Liquid courage on the rise, I jumped on stage with my cohorts for a group effort and then once more on my own. The friendliness of the crowd encouraged these actions; everyone there was like one big support system and the biggest fan of whoever was on stage at any given time.   Songs were $2 a pop, which could add up quickly depending on how much you like the limelight. Our final group song started playing only after we started to make our way towards the exit. In unison, we graced the ears of Japan Town with our loud homage to The Darkness' "I Believe in a Thing Called Love" as we stumbled into the night.

SmjeMKNlfHWjVwQ2sDQKvQ.review_text: Came back into town recently to visit and of course I had to stop by. Had a blast and their lychee martini's are still the best around :)

icl0oYE-ykZ_EHyYtKZmKw.review_text: I just celebrated my 30th birthday at Festa.  The tiny little karaoke bar was perfect for my cozy party of about 30 people.  The folks who run the place are super nice and friendly and the bar/lounge/bathroom are surprisingly clean.  They also let us bring in a birthday cake and provided a knife and extra paper plates at no charge.    The crowd at Festa was awesome.  My friends and I pretty much took over the bar for the entire night and not only did no one complain, everyone sort of just joined in the party.  You can tell there were a few regulars but a couple of the groups looked like they just went to check it out and they were good sports and even helped us celebrate.  The best part was the cheesy backlit cityscape behind the stage which provided the most hilarious backdrop for photos!        They charged us $10 a person cover since we were a large group and took up 80% of the bar but they also threw in 20 free songs which are otherwise $2 a piece.    Despite the extreme smallness of the place or maybe because of it, I had a great time at Festa and would definitely recommend it to people who like karaoke.  It's a change from the usual bar night and even if you're not a singer, you'll be thoroughly entertained.

Z88N6qly3Dp5C06XbZ9IMQ.review_text: There are certain songs that are best left in the privacy of your own shower. These are examples of what you shouldn't sing at Karaoke lounges:  1. Depressing songs -- i.e. I will remember you by Sarah Mclachlan. You may have the voice of an Angel my dear, but this song gets everybody down.  2. Super looong songs -- remember Meatloaf's I will do anything for love? yeah. it goes on F-O-R-E-V-E-R.  3. Prince's songs complete with an exact rendition of Prince's voice. (same goes for the Bee Gees!) Just DON'T. Unless you're cute like my sis then it's okay.  This intimate lounge sure brings the fiesta to Japantown. It's located inside the Kinokuniya strip mall. There isn't a happy hour for drinks, but if you come between 8 - 9pm on Mon - Thurs, songs are free just mention yelp. Otherwise, It's $2 per song (good luck finding it!) if you're like one of those people with crappy memory like I do who can't remember the artist or the exact song title, the thick binder of songs will have you searching for awhile. Plus, you have to watch the screen when your song comes up and make a dash for the stage since there isn't an official DJ here.   You'll have a good time here for sure! The crowd is supportive and it doesn't matter if you've fallen off your chair twice (some guy, not me!) or can't carry a tune, people won't judge you here. Think of it as training ground before unleashing the karaoke queen in you at The Mint.

AETw9Uu23KSsxs6KREz6gw.review_text: Yay Festa!  This place is great.  Damn expensive but oodles of fun.  And it never fails to impress; everyone I've brought here seems to agree it is like no karaoke bar they know.  Come to think of it, it kinda reminds me of the karaoke bar in "Lost in Translation" and if I came here one night and found Bill Murray covering Roxy Music, I might only be mildly surprised.  The space is super intimate which only makes the idea of getting on stage all the more dangerously enticing.  Oh yes, I've seen many a hardcore opponent of karaoke go down at Festa, try as they may!    The best thing about this place?  Number one with a bullet: the stage backdrop!  I think the owner, who is cute as hell and saccharine sweet, nicked it from the set of a Cars video (I'm thinking specifically of "You Might Think", but any would do).  It's pure 80's class, which if you can remember wasn't very classy.  It's classy like that Nagel print you bought from Deck the Walls in '84.  Bring everyone you know here some night, maybe a Tuesday or Sunday night, and just take that joint over.  That's really the best way to do it.

JcDXaiU3uOVAgi_c6JM2Zw.review_text: it was saturday night, I guess that makes it alright ...  actually it was "awesome".  went in at midnight and the place emptied out by 1 am and my friends and I pretty much had the entire place to ourselves.  A LOT cheaper than playground across the street but of course .. you have to share :(  it's a very small and the lighting is waay bright - they need to turn that down a notch.  If you are not comfortable being close enough to sit in someone's lap while you sing, this may not be the place for you.  the song selection is decent and they've got 2 books listed by artist which I like much better than listed by title.  if you are a heavy drinker, its gonna hurt - my last tab was $200+, next time I'm getting nackered somewhere else before heading there.  bartenders are very cool, I highly recommend buying them shots :D

vSTi9G85c5c8RNPFIEMETQ.review_text: This is my best friend's favorite bar. I was rather apprehensive because I really don't like singing in a roomful of strangers. I prefer doing karaoke in a private room with only friends and/or family present. However, this past New Year's Day, after a few drinks, I conquered my shyness and belted out a few tunes on the stage. I was surprised that I wasn't more freaked out. In fact, I had a damn good time.   This bar is quite cozy and intimate, with several tables and chairs set up all over the room. The stage is small with a rather cheesy cityscape backdrop. A TV screen in front of the stage displays song lyrics. The song selection was pretty good - a fair number Western, Japanese, and even Korean tunes.   This Japantown spot is Japanese-owned and bartended. The bartenders are very cool and the atmosphere is lively and fun. The crowd is an eclectic mix of older and younger folks, mostly Asian and Caucasian.   While I still prefer the private karoake room, I would definitely come out to Festa again. And if my friend has her way, it will undoubtedly be soon!

vCyvUmbQkCYct6JXlmXRaQ.review_text: Ah! This place is one of my friend's favorite places for karaoke. This is a nice little bar and karaoke bar. Their lychee martini is yummy and the service is very good here. The only down side to this is that it's so busy on Friday and Saturday nights. If you get there after 10pm, it will be standing room only! Other than that, great place to chill, sing a little, and hang out with friends over a couple of drinks.

Wmx35wh-_dt8cjjDmDsGtA.review_text: So I'm Korean... and I've done more than my fair share of karaoke! While Festa isn't perfect, by any means.. they have an ammmmmmmmmazing selection of music! music! music! I was amazed and basically wanted to sing evvvvverything.  Also, love the decor.

TLzwLBhPoO33w85VOXz97g.review_text: FESTA! Do you think Japanese are all crazy? The answer is .....Yes. youtube.com/watch?v=xnSw… But there are few differences. Japanese from Japan, as JJ. Japanese from Hawaii, as JH. Japanese from North America, as JNA. Japanese from South America, as JSA. Korean from Japan, as KJ Chinese from Japan as CJ. Philippino from Japan, as PJ. They are all crazy ass and grew up with Japanese language. In my case is, I do feel close to all of them. JH and PJ, I think because we are both in a small Island. KJ and CJ they have been there for a long enough and many of them become real JJ. JNA is most different than others. Even though you have parents both from Japan, grew up in North America does make separates. Separates what? What happens living North America? Well, you know, Fat, laud, baseball cap, T-shirts, shorts, FXXXin' birkenstock, white socks and sneakers,.... those. No, that's not a point. That's a good part of US. Do wear whatever you want, but I don't. I just hate shorts. Thing is this, if they speak more text book perfect Japanese gets more obnoxious because sometimes missing the etiquette. I don't really care all hysteric-Japanese etiquette but there is something you shouldn't say certain thing in Japanese especially to older man. To speak older Japanese men is annoyingly difficult because they are such an arrogant prick sometimes. Am I arrogant prick sometimes? FXXX No, well, I try not to. Translate perfect Japanese from English does not make a perfect communication yet between real persons. But, Karaoke? Karaoke. Kuh lah oh kay? Key raw o kee? Do I Karaoke? Hell No. I was always Karaoke hater. I thought Karaoke is such a pathetic Japo-thing. But talking about communication. I found out Karaoke is the thing, universally effective to get together, to be happy to all kind. I had a great Karaoke time at Festa in the west building at Japan Town. It's a small but nice, modern, cozy and cool place for Karaoke & drinks. There are really cool & nice bartenders. I think there were 5 different group of people but it was like a talent show. I liked that no one was pushing me to sing on the stage! That was great. If you don't want to, it's OK. You can have fun too like I did. I still think the guy sang Xanadoo and the theme song for Hanshin Tigers were BLAST! Can you imagine that all of us were singing so loud Xanadu? youtube.com/watch?v=7m1U… Oh FXXX Yeah, we were so gay and I loved it! But the greatest singers were following: Berna Diva Gracy Pho Kay Jay. she isn't Korean Japanese. No one can beat them. No one. So as Ed M. It was his birth day party but we forgot all about it but just singing. Happy Birth day Ed!

Qy-xv4IrZHzdnxoGnyxovQ.review_text: So fabulously giddy that they have S-Club 7's "Never Had A Dream Come True." You simply cannot deny the strange sense of liberation, of empowerment, that getting up on a mini stage and singing in front of total strangers gives! All of a sudden you find yourself grasping onto the mic just a little bit more, that sort of thing. Karaoke is to have fun and Festa, without a doubt, provides a fun atmosphere where patrons can sing the blues, wail about love, and anything else their little hearts desire. When there are more than 2 singers on stage, they ever so graciously provide another mic. Nice touch, as not everyone wants to be just another back up singer. Ahhh, minor detail: Requested water, and was brought a bottle of it. Hmmm. Like I said, minor detail. Belt it out, honey.

-TV1mL9W8CFxzpFLKtwL_Q.review_text: Festa lounge staff are very friendly. Great drinks. Great decor. Awesome place to have fun with a group and karaoke!!

DiAUiaoDKFlifJK0FCkEWg.review_text: I would like to being with... The owner? The fancy lady who is also in this pictures... she does look mighty fancy, and that fancy factor alone gave you a star, so it saved you from a two star rating.   So lets begin...   1. You are a small little venue that makes it hard to believe that my imaginary manager would book a venue that small to rock out in.   2. I guess your drinks are a bit pricey. I spent $22.00 on two drinks, and decided that: -a. I will not be drunk enough to rock, out especially in a venue so small that it wouldn't be able to contain all the glory that is... DANTASTICO!  -b. I had already had 2 liters of beer for free so I wasn't jones'n for more alcohol.   3. What the hell city scape in the background of the stage is that supposed to be? Toronto?   4. I will admit, it is one of the more... fancy karaoke bars I have been to, especially in San FranDisco.   5. The patrons there are magical. Everyone clapped for everyone, everyone was a back up singer for everyone, even if they didn't know the words to the songs... ITS KARAOKE there are words on the t.v screens so everyone was able to do back up vocals.   6. You have a good list of song options, BUT not a great list of song options... yeah I said it.   7.You turned me down! YOU TURNED ME DOWN WHEN I WAS GOING TO SING BOHEMIAN RHAPSODY!.... Whats wrong with yoooou!? Don't you know who I'm not!  all in all, it was quite an enjoyable night.

f6jNWRAxqR0UmAR2jvtNFQ.review_text: What fun!  This attractive little hideaway in SF's Japantown is a jewel.  Knowledgeable bartenders create your drink of choice and go ahead - take a stab at karaoke! The lists of songs are huge and you are sure to find one you like. Great place to meet friends and have a lively evening. You'll love it.

Z9bOjahuxvMju3mO3ac9_g.review_text: ahaha i ALWAYS have fun here!! there are definitely regulars that i always see no matter what day i go, but everyones nice, and its fun to sing in front of people  they've got a full bar, and cool people working there  def helps if u speak japanese (i don't).  the crowd is a mix of young asians in a group to old white guys there by themselves. whatever, everyone's there to have fun, and everyone does.  $2 per song, so make sure u make it count

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: Been here about a million times but had a HELLA bad experience tonight.  The girl working here tonight pissed me off. I walked in late on a Sunday night - place was very quiet and there was hardly a queue for songs.  My family was visiting from Puerto Rico and had never heard me sing, and had never seen karaoke. I said - is it OK for me to sing one song. This young girl working there (Caucasian) had such an attitude. She was drinking a beer, and made me buy an $8 water. After the transaction, she lectured me on how everyone has to order a drink. It was so awkward. I told her I had been there a thousand times and would be happy to pay extra to just sing - that we were full and weren't going to stay long. t could understand if the place wasn't empty, or if I hadn't already paid for the overpriced Voss water. More than the policy, she just gave me the heebie jeebies.  I'd like to emphasize that my issue was more with the *ATTITUDE* than the POLICY.

O1yqX-Blt6ntmsndo2wT7w.review_text: So much fun!  This is a perfectly-designed Karaoke lounge.  The atmosphere is friendly and the stage is optimally set up for full enjoyment of performances.  (That said, poor performances and song choices are somewhat of an issue, but I can't deduct stars for the clientele...)  I would come back every week just to sing my guts out and watch others do the same!

rS4OEY7fWDZG_JuJjR9HWg.review_text: I went here with a friend one Tuesday evening and we had a really great time singing. The joint is small and intimate, so it feels like you're singing to a contingent of friends. Beware if you show up on a Saturday night it's worse than going to the DMV... there's a crowd spilling out the door.  I found the cheese plate to be a waste of money. If you typically have cheese plates at restaurants, you'll be sorely disappointed with what Festa is offering... a couple of blah American cheeses and some soda crackers? Hmpf.  Since I haven't lived here for very long, I've not had a chance to visit many karaoke bars in the city. However, I find it mildly offensive that they charge $2 per song to sing. When I'm racking up a hefty tab from drinking their $10 cocktails all night, I expect the karaoke to be gratis. But maybe that's a San Francisco thing. The staff is friendly and the crowd is fun, but I won't be returning.

KltM7KJixE6NksDGXaRZWg.review_text: Are you the type of person who has no shame? Do you sing in the shower? Do you think you can carry a tune even if your friends say you can't? If you answered yes to all of the above, then you are just what Festa is looking for on a nightly basis. Located in the heart of Japan Town, this karaoke bar is just what you need to prove your friends wrong. Rock the mic without shame and I assure you, the crowd will be behind you 100 percent!   I'm more accustomed to private room style karaoke where the only people who can witness your shamelessness are the people in your group (usually your "so-called" friends). This type of karaoke should be more intimidating but once you realize that the people that go up on stage ahead of you don't have any qualms about looking like complete idiots, your confidence will take a significant spike.   It's funny how cheesy 80's and 90's songs bring everyone together. At one point, I got up there and rocked "Semi Charmed Kind Of Life" with some drunk sot who was up there butchering the song. Everyone in there, regardless of which group they belong to, always cheers you on and sings along no matter how off key you are. I guess that's why it's always a good idea to pair karaoke with alcohol. Can you imagine how we must sound without it?  Good times!  4.4 stars

UvrisvZ9TIpBJ7s7l3NsXg.review_text: I have to agree with Megan C.  The scene is really cool in appearance here... but don't be fooled!  First, the cokes were $5.  Seriously.  The guy told me, "it's on the menu," but it wasn't.  Then he said "you should have asked what the price was before ordering it... what did you expect it would cost?"  This was not a supersize coke.  It was in a whiskey-type glass.    OK, whatever.  The KJ was totally discriminatory towards our table.  Some people, even those who came after us, sang four songs to our one.    I really like the scene, but the super rude staff and ridiculous mark-ups on drinks will keep me away... there are much better places in the city!

duFP2mFpWc-qc21T5XKvNg.review_text: I recently discovered Festa because my good friend and fellow Yelper Bobby L. just can't stop going here and introduced me to this little gem.  Located in Japantown in the Kinokuniya plaza, you'd not find this place easily if you didn't know what you were looking for!!  We usually come here weeknights so parking is usually never a problem :)  The place is small!  Really small!!!  Like, maybe, 50 people max and it will be really crowded with that many.  I'd put the comfortable capacity at about 30 people.  Which is perfect for most of us aspiring singers - get on stage without the stage fright of having to sing before an audience of 100 plus people :D  Fortified of course, by the awesome drinks from the bar :)  Songs are a very reasonable $2 each - for this, you get the privilege of getting on stage and belting out your favorite number to your heart's content!  I love the staff as well as the people who frequent this place.  You can tell several are repeat and regular customers which always speaks well of a place in my opinion.  I've been here twice and I know I will be back here many many more times.  It's a fun place filled with friendly people and people having a good time.  You can't go wrong with that recipe :)  ~ 4 stars overall - there's no doubt in my mind I'll be back here.  Soon.  # 233

MrNmuLOMTPbhAJgA2xo4fQ.review_text: If you are ever looking to hang with Japanese businessmen, this is the place to be. During my time in Japan, I learned that Karaoke, and drinking (particularly whiskey) were key components of the post-work routine for Japanese professionals. It's not wonder that you can often find Japanese tourists/businessmen hanging around here in Festa, drinking sake, and belting out american and japanese ballads.  The drinks here are excellent. While on the girly side, the Peach Bellini and the Sparkling Sake were great. Of course, I didn't order either--I wrapped my manly paws around chivas in a whiskey tumbler. But perhaps my companion ordered some and was overly gracious in her sharing.

rP1JhMcc7sZTzW3KzLpL9w.review_text: LOVED IT!!!  A friend of mine had a birthday party here and it was such a fun experience! The place itself is pretty small.. you go in, there's a bathroom in the hallway (which was spacious and clean!), then the room opens up with the bar on the right and the tables and stage. That's it. But it is the fact that it's small that makes it even better! You get a really warm feeling, everyone is friendly to each other and the popular songs get sung by the the whole crowd.   $2 a song, with a really good selection (it's guaranteed that everyone will find something they'll want to sing) and still the feeling of being a star when you get on the stage. The wait for the songs isn't bad either, and the waiting list is displayed at the end of every song so people can get ready. Overall, a really fun place with reasonable prices and good service. I had one drink and it was strong, and I'm sure every one else's were too. My only thing was that one of the two microphones wasn't working as well as the other one, and being a Singstar on Singstar.. I've grown to be a little picky about sound.   Despite that, I can't wait to come back and fill the place up with my singing friends!!!!!!!!!!!

k_7Ii_BNYDocMr3bUeJgFw.review_text: WOW, I really wish Yelp had a negative star feature.   The Staff and Owner are RACISTS and LGBT crowd haters, while also being out right thieves.   FESTA is a small, odd & yet interestingly conceptual place.   WHEN you can get the staff to bother paying attention to you and get your drink order which they are supposed to do, they take their time like we are serving them...They need to remember the customer is the person being served (not them), wait staff is supposed to serve their customers in a polite, warm and inviting way so customers will return, insuring wait staff income to live.   A date introduced this place to me in November of 2008. They were rude from the first second we walked in....it took forever to get a drink and them they were wrong every time we order another round.   Paying eight bucks a glass for a wine that I would not serve mass murders is a crime. Ever changing pricing is illegal and a crime here.   The wait staff was suspicious of my date and I at first, but they were making too much fun and saying disgustingly ignorant remarks about a table of women that they concluded were lesbians. When they when they realized we were gay became out right offensive. They talked about us, not realizing that between the two of us we understood fag comments in the several languages they tried to hide their barbaric attitudes.   All night long PEOPLE complained about not getting to sing their songs. That is because we found out later after some people left not getting their requests is because if you are not a friend of the owners then you are screwed. They charge $2.00 for the song request, then keep the money after not playing them and they use the money to buy drinks later. If they were an intelligent customer serve oriented business they could just keep a simple list in order to request songs and avoid the whole thing, but no they deliberately piss off paying customers.   If your WHITE in this bar, forget it, the owner and staff are going to make you pay for whatever transgression every white person has ever done to anyone in the history of the planet. And God forbid you are Asian, but not Japanese, you are even more screwed.   I think everyone on Yelp should call the Mayor's Office, Police Dept and the Human Rights Commission and complain about illegal business practice, racism and hate crimes toward the LGBT community. Then we could form a class action suit and sue their asses out of business.   And for the Japan Town business community, I feel sorry because this place does not reflect the good people that run professional businesses in anyway....it just hurts that community.   They should change the name to FESTER, because that is what it does and one day someone will lance the boil of that Festering place supposed there to serve people.

FdbS53mLhoLazosBDURrzA.review_text: Festa's is my favorite place to sing karaoke in San Francisco. Good atmosphere with a good sound system for singing, very friendly people and wait staff, and good drinks. A nice size place for karaoke also. Everyone has a god time here. A friend took me here years ago, and I still come to Festa's when I am in San Francisco.

UVxY0iyPaqY7s4BSFtt-xA.review_text: Small, intimate Karaoke Bar upstairs in the Japan Center in the Kinokuniya building near the internal bridge overpass.   Japanese owned. The older couple sitting at the end of the bar helps with the welcome feel, with the classy lady smiling you in, and the gentleman sitting next to her at the end of the bar, getting up and singing old favorites in the slow moments. The tall, thin, younger male and female bartenders are Japanese, too.   Huge songbook with many current releases in large binders. Lotsa J-Pop, but tons of American favorites, too, in any genre.   One small stage with a small LCD monitor for the singers. A handful of tables and a small bar.   Most Americans call this activity like they're lifting and hauling a redneck, or "Carry Okie".     The Japanese pronunciation is like them telling you the vehicle they drive is in good condition, or "Car, uh, Okay!"  This place is packed on the weekends, so try coming on a school night for more singing opportunities. No private rooms.

YbZg36FoMgkKcTEPae5siA.review_text: This place is tiny so don't plan on bringing a whole army of friends here. I'm glad we didn't have a huge group with us or it would've been tough to get our songs played. They charge $2 a song and they don't announce your name so you really have to pay attention if you want to sing. The song selection is pretty good. They even have songs in Japanese if that's your thing. I witnessed several people singing songs in Japanese here - bartender included.  There's a one drink minimum so be ready to shell out at least $9 for a cocktail. The bartenders are pretty good here. We didn't wait very long to be served and they seemed happy to take our orders.  We must've went on a pretty good night because it wasn't overly crowded until later and most of us got our songs played rather quickly.   I didn't realize they had a bathroom here until the night was almost over. Instead, I ran downstairs into the Japan Center mall.  I'd probably go back but I don't know how many songs I'd sing since they'd already be getting my money for a drink and at least one song.

QF9vzRcKOUn32wgnTcTG9Q.review_text: The five star rating still stands.  No question.    That said, I am dismayed by the ingratitude and cheapness regularly demonstrated by a lot of the hipster patrons who would drunkenly dispute a tab they festively racked up buying rounds of shots for their friends, and after having their itemized bill thoroughly run down for them, still leave a 5 percent tip for the bartenders who have to put up with a lot of pushy customers who bitch about their songs not being played two minutes after they put in their request.  I've taken for granted the fun derived from people watching.  The bartenders make the bar.  Not the hoards of tools singing their crap cornier than my leavings after eating a Chipotle burrito.

AAI8mmWem4zQU7qanPrOmg.review_text: I have a confession to make! Promise not to tell anyone?  Okay... I have a fetish for people speaking the Japanese language... Is that weird? So if you ever see me; please don't (and by that, I mean please do) bust out with the Japanese... You'll make me weak in the knees and have butterflies in my stomach.  So I wrote my chinese name on a piece of paper and challenged Koji (bartender) to read it. He had me clapping like the happiest sea lion in the world!  This place is small, but cozy. I don't think they even have their own restroom, you'll have to use one somewhere in the plaza.  But don't worry, you won't drink to the point where you'll throw up; because it would be such a waste to throw up 9-12 dollar delicious, well-made cocktail drinks!  I remember long ago when I made a promise to myself that I'd never sing at a karaoke bar...   I broke that promise.                 I got up and sang my two-dollar song, "More Than Words" by Extreme.  Thank God I had the balls and liquor courage to do that... Because I ain't doing that again!!!  Now what the hell did he put in my drink to get me to do that???

s93PtWbODlx8h5IK86CVSA.review_text: I feel very bad for T.J. down below who had a really bad experience here, because when I've gone, I've felt like Festa has a really positive, welcoming atmosphere.  Nice hostesses and bartenders, and I just like the idea of being able to pay per song and just hang out for a few hours without having to pay a "per hour" fee like private karaoke rooms.   Pretty good drinks too. My favorite so far has been the lychee cocktail. The Blue Tokyo is a little too strong for me, and the saketini is.. interesting. If you like sake, you'll probably like it.   There is a wide range of singers/people that come here. You don't have to be the "karaoke-type" to enjoy it. You seem to get them all here-- Japanophiles singing in Japanese, Asian people, non-Asian people, good singers, amazing singers, not so good singers, older Korean lady belting out cheesy Korean songs. Good oldies seem to dominate the list of requested songs.    The downside:  Here are some reasons why I knocked off 2 stars. - The price of the drinks. I know a cocktail for $9-10 isn't ridiculous, but... it gets old after a couple of drinks, and I wish they had more of a variety on their menu. They basically have expensive cocktails, cheaper beer ($5-10), and very expensive wine.   - the selection of the songs. Ya, they have Japanese and Korean songs, and a great selection of older songs, but their newest page (as of March) was songs from January 2010, and even then, they didn't have any Gaga! This complaint is really only half-serious, but how could you not have any Gaga? Even just a few from her first album?? Maybe they don't wanna hear it every night.   - the wait-time for your requested songs. Our group waited about 30 minutes for one song, and about an hour for our second song, even though we requested them within one minute of each other. You definitely have to come in, sit down, request a song first, and then buy drinks, enjoy yourselves, etc. If you hold off too long to request a song, your wait time will just get longer and longer. Definitely a different kind of karaoke experience for me, because I'm used to private rooms. Just keep in mind that you can't just decide at the last minute you wanna sing something--

YMxJL6OrtPT8SeZfBaFH5w.review_text: Came here w/ the sis as we were waiting for our table at Mum's.  We were actually pleasantly surprised as to how the place looked.  We chatted to our polite bartender about how the place is.  She said that it got pretty full on the weekends.  My sister asked her to make a drink and it came out wrong.  We asked her if she could fix it and gladly did w/ much apology.  We also had a lychee martini which was very tasty.  The karaoke book they had had everything under the sun from pop songs, love songs, songs in Chinese and Filipino!

fQuLe-KuojSco4DRbcFpGw.review_text: this place marks the very first time i sang karaoke in public. i don't care what other people say: i have star quality, dammit!  i call my singing style "eccletic experimental yodel folk". have you ever sang fleetwood mac's dreams in the voice of jennifer tilly and the timing of both tricky and prince circa 1995? didn't think so. cuz then you'd be biting my steez.  serenading my pitbull with my own rough rendition of george clinton's atomic dog while she stares at me with her ears bent back just doesn't count. NOBODY PUTS BABY IN THE CORNER!  so for all you jennifer greys out there with the fat luther vandross stuck inside of you, go to festa for your first stab at this obnoxious pasttime! the crowd is tolerant (and small), there's no interior visibility from the outside (so you can save face), they have a decent soju/sake selection, and the service is friendly.  oh, and it's LEGAL! it's a perfect stepping stone towards ultimate voluntary public humiliation, which is auditioning for american idol and not being picked, a la william hung.  go!

TNWQuWa3kLH2Llx10LW1Yw.review_text: the bartenders are always cute and polite. the videos need an upgrade into this century. the drinks are pricey for a place that's essentially inside a strip mall. thanks, that is all.

h8pthOnqCxV94D8-JkZXCQ.review_text: I have never karaoked like this before!  A stage?!  Singing in front of total strangers?!  What happened to the little private rooms with the disco ball and plasma TV with strange Asian music videos????    Needless to say, I was a little intimidated.  I was there with the veterans!    First of all, you have these 4 huge song books.. alphabetized by song title, artist, or language.  You pick a song, write it down on a piece of paper (I think it's $2 a song?), and wait for your turn.  It was sooooo nerve-wracking!  I was scared I was going to crack.. or worse.. what if I get boo'ed off?!    But I had such a blast!  The first time is always the scariest, but everyone was there cheering everyone else on.  Plus, it's not a very place.  There's a full bar, maybe 5 tables with booth seating, the small stage, and a bathroom. You'll probably never see these people again, so it's ok to embarrass yourself.  AND, they were all pretty drunk, so everyone's just having a grand ol' time :)  I love it.  I don't think I'm ever going back to traditional karaoke :)

fHS0bQ-l5rHME_xXKQSYXQ.review_text: If you figure one universal karaoke truism is that you don't always win at karaoke 'cause you can best belt out your favorites -- you win at karaoke on style points -- Festa might well prove the most apt metaphor for karaoke going. Tucked in the side pocket of a shopping mall in Japantown, I happened in here on the tip of some folks in the know for an evening of revelry and off-kilter crooning.   The best part about Festa has to be that they don't announce your track - essentially, you have to pay attention -- and even then -- once your song starts, you have to haul ass to get up there in time for the beginning (or chorus, or coda, or whatever's left) of your song. This results in more than the requisite helping of hilarity, and at some point in the night a pack of my group camped out on stage for what no doubt seemed like four and a half years. Shorter to run, I gather. I love the cityscape backdrop, a tiny homage to the city surrounding (and cities everywhere, I gather). And like most knock offs in this place, packed with personality.

myC_mD2WIkvpcJb1wFnV1g.review_text: Went here last minute for a quick drink around 1am right before last call on a Monday night. The place is small but very well decorated with a decent karaoke stage in the corner of the room. Drinks were strong (too strong for my gin and tonic. It tasted like straight gin but some may like that! ) and a little on the higher end price-wise (16 for the gin and tonic and a bud light in a bottle).   The bartender was a bit rude, forgot our beer and acted put off that I reminded her about it. We only ended up staying a few minutes before she came to our table and told us that they would be closing early due to lack of customers (there were at least 11 other people in the place, which was a decent amount considering the size). We weren't even halfway done with our drinks before they were kicking us out, which was a huge turnoff. I've never been booted out of a bar before (well, only when I've been a bit naughty) and it made us uncomfortable, so we left without even finishing our drinks. Wish we had made it a block further and headed to the Boom Boom Room instead. We won't be returning.

KeCR-77rIw-rWUAYa7O3Bw.review_text: This place is a terrible rip-off. A one (very overpriced) drink minimum AND karaoke charged by the song? Come on guys, choose one or the other.  So my group comes in, gives them money for a few songs, and sits down. So they charge per song and don't even have a DJ to call names? You have to pay attention to the screen or you might miss your song. Whatever.  Usually when there's a minimum someone comes up to you and asks for your order right away, but we weren't approached for about 30 minutes. When they did, they asked if we ordered a drink and that they found a whiskey bottle near our table. They falsely accused us of sneaking it in, and told us that if we didn't order drinks that we'd have to leave - never mind the fact that we already put in money for karaoke and were still waiting for one more song. Thankfully the song came up, I belted the tune, and we promptly left.  Rude staff, rude owner, overpriced drinks, karaoke charged by the song. I am never coming back.

-jvNk13xR2-M2kV3Ylyxbw.review_text: I didn't really like coming here with my friends and I. They charge 2 dollars per song, which is pretty pricey. And I put in a song, and other people sang two or three times before I could. I asked them what happened, and they couldn't find the song, and then they found it and said I was next, but then 3 other people sang instead, then I asked again, and they said I was next, but then another person sang again, until I was next.  When I asked them about it they said they organized the song order by table. But I don't know how that explains how I waited an hour and a half to sing a song, and other people sang 2 or 3 times. They didn't seem to care though, so I would rather like to just never come here again.  One last thing I'd like to mention, me and my friends ordered tea here, which cost $5 each. Sounds really expensive for tea, yeah, but I've spent that much at tea lounges before, and it's usually worth it, but they gave us the cheapest brand of tea you can get for $1 a box in chinatown. It was a complete and utter rip-off.

u_S974PQHPNoGkdst27F6w.review_text: I went back to festa lounge again. Every time I go there I have such a great time. I don't sing!! but still great place to hang out friends. I love people who works there. I love there even you are alone, you can enjoy a cocktail.

f874Y8CQ59wKrzornHlFlQ.review_text: Hot damn they charge $9 bucks for drinks, $4 for a cup of green tea, and $2 bucks for each song!  Ridiculous.  Also embarrassing is the size of Festa, maybe 400 square feet, you can see everything, and everyone from anywhere in the bar.    Price gouging and claustrophobia aside, I like this place.  It's clean, efficient, and perfect for jeering or cheering your friends on.  Not to mention there's a fun cardboard skyline backdrop on stage, backlit with Christmas lights, and part of the ceiling twinkles with fake stars.  It makes all those sappy love ballads, and slow jams all the more authentic.    Get in early.  I went from 8 pm and stayed till 2 am, and discovered it gets packed at  around 10:30 pm, and a second wave settles in at around 12:30 am.    Overall, a nice establishment I could take my mother to.    Note: the volume doesn't get adjusted.  Bring ear plugs, and fist wads of cash or plastic.  Some songs are in Japanese or Chinese (not sure), and the crowd is well-mannered clean, and wholesome.  For a dirtier night out- with cheaper drinkers, and cheaper people- I'm a fan of Encore on California St.

Ct456aEICzDfn03MHZCzsw.review_text: Hey, sorry haven't been in the warbling mood for a while and since my singling tomodachi requested karaoke in J-town, thought this space would work and WOW...Sachi is now called FESTA...getcho FESTA on for a biggu biggu checkkkuuu. But it was FUN for once in a blue moon entertainment value. (But in reading the other guys reviews, beware of those screaming, obnoxiolla, amoebas crawling and drawling their bad juju into noFESTA,justaPesta.)

MDQHCmuIB6WF01aqExEfXw.review_text: Karaoke brings out the inner rockstar supernova in all of us. A small group of friends and I dominated here last weekend for a birthday party. When I say dominated, the place is small and it is very easy to cruise in, feel comfy and get the party started. The atmosphere is intimate and  non-intimidating, which promotes everyone to sing, even those that should keep their lyrical talents private can be found screaming their asses of. It's a good mix of people, only problem is pricey drinks and $2.00 songs and ultra long waits. So if you plan on putting on a performance, better get a few songs lined up at once. All in all, fun experience, did someone say mic check 1...2...?

IpXqOHIFUZN6YD9KhVIIJw.review_text: This is the best place for Karaoke in the city. Good stage and good crowd. They have a good selection of song. The bartenders are pretty nice. Pretty small place*********** Place is well decorated and better ambience. Karaoke bar and the staff are friendly.

LFha-r2VljAzN13YwySTXw.review_text: I remember stepping onto the stage,  my song of choice playing in the background while lyrics hit the screen... all the while with an obnoxiously mischievous look on my face.  FESTA IS AWESOME. It's my favorite place to go for karaoke, hands down! Great staff, great venue, all kinds of alcoholic brands to choose from including sake and soju and FUN!  I can't wait to go back again...

XNAgIeA4UNqcMOcLA70qDg.review_text: I am a fan of karaoke bars and will saunter up to the microphone in a dive bar or a classy joint.  I was excited when I walked into Festa to see such a nice atmosphere and hear an older gentleman singing some Sinatra. I thought then that I was in for a good night, but boy was I wrong.  I don't even know where to begin.  I went on a Friday not expecting to get a million songs in, but hoping for at least 1 or 2.  I understand how the queuing process generally works at karaoke bars, so I had no problem putting in a couple song requests, having a couple drinks, taking in the other performances, and waiting. The cost per song here is $2, which is fine by me if that means less people will be inundating the KJ with drunken song requests.    I watched as the same people came up to the stage over and over, as many as 4 times, before anyone in my party even got a single song in.  It was not a question of the other people getting to the bar before us- I saw them come in at least 20 minutes after I arrived at Festa.  As the night passed, I realized that some of the repeat singers were friends of the owner.  They were seated at a table that we were told was reserved for a large party.  When the party came in, I was asked to move from my non-reserved table to make up for the space that the friends were taking at the table that had been reserved.  If the table moving experience wasn't enough of an annoyance, my song NEVER came up.  After 90 minutes had passed, I inquired about my song and saw it about 3 songs back in the queue atop a large stack of my groups requests (some of which had been paid for in cash in advance at the bar).  30 minutes later my song still didn't come up.  When I asked about it this time, hoping for a real explanation, the KJ said that it was the way the line worked and assured me it was all fair, and that my song was still 5 songs away.  So after 2 hours of patiently waiting, cheering on other singers, and buying drinks, I told the KJ to remove all my songs requests.  When I went to close out my tab, I was charged an 18% automatic gratuity for being a part of a group of 6 or more people.  Granted, there were 6 of us, but we were never served as a group, and none of the others were charged this gratuity.  It seemed to have been made up on the spot.  And after 2 hours of being ignored, I was in no mood to leave a tip at all, none the less an 18% tip.  The entire night my group got 3 songs in TOTAL while EACH REGULAR got AT LEAST 2 songs in, and as many as 4.  It really is a shame, I was ready to give up on other karaoke spots in favor of the warm ambiance of Festa.  But after being treated as I was, I can't say that I will ever go back.    Only go here if you are a friend of the owner.  Don't go in groups of 6, don't make friends with another table so they think you are a group of 6.  But better still, just go somewhere else where you won't be treated like shit.

DhSbHfqhjoFZ-nmsgwZXBg.review_text: I came here on Saturday night around 8 pm and the place was  packed. Luckily our friends had gotten tables for us, so we don't have to wait long for. table. i ordered peach Bellini and it was ok. A little bit sweet to my liking and a little to pricey. The crowd was great, and some people really have good voice. it was entertaining.  The spund system was good, song options were many and up to date. $2/song was ok, although you can wait for some time for your song to show up. i had a good time and would come back.

uZdFsE_aHbFBChgN6Xa8tw.review_text: This place is in the mall so people that come here purposely do.  It's a tacky karaoke stage and the bar itself is really small.  I can tell the service is good - they keep it clean by clearing alcohol glasses and wiping down the tables.  I probably would not come back unless the whole place was rented out with my friends, which means a private karaoke room would be more efficient.

09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w.review_text: There are no separate private rooms here but you'll still like it. Not the typical karaoke joint that have rooms for rental and you pay by the hour - the typical karaoke experience. Here, it's all about the on-stage experience. Warbling and all this is the karaoke I go most often now. Songs are $2 per, which is not cheap compared to other places. The drinks are not cheap either but also not super expensive. The money saved on not renting a room goes towards my drinks, yeah! Factor in the cost of renting a private room the bill for the night is actually cheaper. And, like at any bar or club or lounge you should become a regular. Then, the bartenders will treat you better. I like the staff here, very friendly but not displaying favoritism like at other venues. Note there are other karaoke joints in the Bay Area that has a stage for singing, some of them have rooms and some don't. I still prefer having both options so can pick and choose depending on the group. It's really a four star venue but the bartenders and owner earned the final star. Bonus: youtube.com/TheKARAOKECh… youtube.com/singkingkara…

VMkROPn0M45Ga7h4osJuqA.review_text: Small, intimate, public karaoke bar that delivers on big entertainment and guaranteed to make you feel like a rock star even though your caterwauling is making everyone's ears bleed.    By small and intimate, I mean just that.  The place is no bigger than a two car garage.  There are no booths, just you, the stage, and untapped glory.  You may be intimidated by singing in public, but you need not fear this place because no one here will judge you.  Everyone is supportive, they know the lyrics, and they'll sing along with you.  Afterward, when you're done making a mockery of yourself, the audience will clap and cheer you on.  There's no greater ego boost, deserved or not.  I, myself, am a terrible singer.  But the atmosphere, and camaraderie lead me to fearlessly sing My Girl with fearless abandon.  I surprised myself.  Sure, liquid courage helps somewhat, but the enthusiasm of this place is infectious.   That, combined with the clean, cushy interior sets this place apart from other whole in the wall places that make you afraid for your safety.

DCnWy4XBG6ZiEquVqoCLOw.review_text: I karaoke a lot, and Festa is my favorite place to karaoke in SF. It's the perfect mix of intimate space, public stage, and convenient bar at the ready--instead of having to smuggle alcohol into those little karaoke studios. Plus, Festa has the best song selection--other studios either don't have a lot of good songs or the musical accompaniment sounds like a 7-year old playing on their Casio keyboard for you. And let's not even talk about the weird videos other studios show while your song is playing.  I've witnessed others having a bad time at Festa, and it's usually because they're totally hammered or they expect Diva service. Public drinking and karaoke can get really messy, and I often sympathize with the staff at Festa because the crowd often gets unruly, especially towards the end of the night.  I highly recommend going to Festa early in the evening during the week. (The drinks are cheaper and songs are free before 9:30.) All of your requests will be played immediately and you get excellent service. Once the place gets packed around 9:30/10pm, all hell can break loose, and at that point you just need to go with the flow.

zKm4j3JJLgnqe1F3q_qZFg.review_text: I had very little expectations about coming here last night for my friend's birthday.  I am not a karaoke girl.. I sing in my car, I sing at concerts, heck I even sing in taxi cabs if I'm drunk enough!   But I'm not big on singing in front of crowds.  This place. Is. Awesome.  Great drinks--lychee martini, phone book sized song selection--in English and Japanese (if you're into Asian pop music).  Nice cozy environment and really really cool bartenders!  Thanks for cleaning up after us last night!

mowGolovKzs6HmiIjtL-gA.review_text: This is the best karaoke bar in the City.  Don't come.  : )

xr5DO7X4pz1IK-Et-M1rXw.review_text: I've spent two evenings at Festa.  Beautiful, intimate room, good cocktails and karaoke. Charging for each karaoke song on top of expensive drinks seems excessive, but I rolled with it.  I brought 30 friends there on my birthday, was happy to pay a serving fee for bringing my own birthday cake (to be expected in nice restaurants) I offered a piece to all the servers and was stunned when a bartender smiled at me later and pointed to my cake turned on it's side in a box on the floor next to the door.  Seriously,  WTF?!!!  Second visit I gave a credit card to run a tab.  Had 4 drinks and was presented with a bill for $70 with room to leave a tip.  When I asked for an itemized receipt, my drinks were not only overpriced, but an 18% service charge was added without explanation. I ordered these at the bar, not even table service.  I was then asked "wasn't I with a group of 6 or more?"  I've worked in restaurants and this is a dirty and greedy trick.  If I ever go back, I'll bring a flask.

AzN4B04BxO5bV1lvSou8Qg.review_text: $2.00 per kareoke song.....  Like other reviews, I"m not sure how I feel about paying to sing kareoke.  I'm already there buying drinks.  I guess I"m spoiled by the other kareoke bars  I"ve been to where you don't pay to sing.  But the two bartenders were really nice and even chatted with us a bit at the bar.  No drink specials when we were there Sat night, at least none that I saw or heard of.  This place is located in the Kinokuniya plaza.  We stayed at the kabuki next door, but if you need parking there's a lot in this plaza down below.  You can easily miss it if you're not looking out for it.   It's a really small spot with no actual stage.   You could basically sing a song from your table. There's some chairs and tables and maybe 8 stools at the bar.   I guess this would be great if the whole room is you and your friends, otherwise get ready to share Festa with say 20 of your closest strangers.

1f33vJNISFbw0GaMYpEncw.review_text: I crashed a birthday party at Festa after a Yelp Elite event on a Wednesday night.   Funny story: There's only one bathroom here. I was waiting for it, when the birthday boy sat down to wait, too. Knowing that he was the birthday boy, I introduced myself and said he could go first unless he was going to pee all over the seat. He said he could hold it, and shoved me toward the bathroom. When I came out, he was on the stage singing "Poison" by Bell Biv DeVoe with his friend.   (which is a great transition to my next thought)  My thoughts on public karaoke in the words of Bell Biv DeVoe:   If I were you I'd take precautionnnn...  before doing karaoke with Yelpers, because the odds are, one of them has it recorded on their camera.   And if you slight one of them, ooooh, that might surface on the Internet.   But then again, my threshold for public humiliation might be really low, so what do I know?

aqWXHhcR_CdmKmxggFOlEA.review_text: I am not a big karaoke person but as far as karaoke places go, Festa is pretty cool.  The fake scenic background is perfect for photo opportunities, and the mini-stage is also great for you and your back-up singers.  There is a pretty good selection of songs, though they were missing one of my friend's favorite karaoke songs - Bye Bye Bye by N Sync.  The drinks are a bit pricey - $9 for specialty drinks like their martinis - but tasty (I had the lychee martini).  The place is pretty small so if you're going with a large group (like I did), you should call ahead so space is reserved because the place was packed when we were there.

djxnI8Ux8ZYQJhiOQkrRhA.review_text: Quite possibly the best karaoke spot in the entire Bay Area...   Nestled in a Japantown shopping center, this is an itty bitty bar. You could easily walk by and miss it altogether, especially since it doesn't get bumpin' until way after all of the surrounding stores are closed. If you walk in and see an unidentified skyline on the small stage, you know you've come to the right place.  What I like best about this particular karaoke joint is the fact that everyone pays $2 to sing and there's no cheeseball KJ there to sweet talk. Just write down your song selection, hand it to the bartender and they'll queue it up and add the monies to your overall tab. Brilliant! This way, it's all fair and square.  I've been here a handful of times and it's always a blast. Since the setting is so intimate, it's impossible not to get  caught up into whatever song the person on stage is singing. Definitely a great place to make new friends. Or run into existing ones, like I did the other night when I ran into Bobby L and a few other South Bay yelpers :) BTW, what were you guys doing so far from San Jose so late????

zORQY85qUfWiIEltLOxG1g.review_text: Warning do not go here if you're feeling EMO.  You'll end up crying in your martini glass after hearing every breakup/emo songs in the book.  This may cause you to drink even more and then to eventually text your ex something along the lines of, "why did we break up again?"  "Because you cheated on me bitch!" kidding.  The lichee martini is like no other.  At first I was a bit iffy about the place.  I mean it really is as small as my dining room and you have to PAY to sing karaoke.  Also the drinks are overpriced.  But man, they really know how to make good drinks.  After 4 glasses, you'll definitely have no shame singing along.  Another thing, you'll spend the whole time at Festa planning to download the songs you hear, but fail to do so when you go home because you'll totally forget what songs they were.  Damn Sake Martini!  I enjoyed my experience... +3.5 for the amazing lichee martini and for the mixed crowd.  Maybe because the place seems small and intimate or because everyone there was drunk...regardless, we all had no shame in making a fool of ourselves.

JFRdv_Q9-f8I7Q1pbnwVCg.review_text: Sadly our experience tonight was disappointing. I have been here before a few times and loved the vibe, even celebrated my birthday here last year. Tonight I went with my boyfriend. We put in 6 songs around 8:30pm. By 10:15pm the KJ had played two of our songs and a million of everyone else's. I wouldn't have minded if it were crowded, but there were a total of 9 other people in the room, five of which sang multiple songs within that two hour stretch.  The bartender kindly refunded me the $8 for our songs because it's a work night and we had to go home. But I couldn't help but feel a bit put out. What's the deal? Is there something we should know in order to get our songs played or was this just a disorganized fluke?

x4hSo91JUPcp3w5wwEg5Ng.review_text: Here's what you get on a Fri/Sat night:  the place is packed, the cost for a song is $2, you hand your $10 bill to the karaoke attendant who asks you if you want change. Obviously you do. But not if you want your song to come up in the next 90 minutes. She/he takes your $8 tip and then calculates your spot in the sea of paid slips. $20 will get you pretty close to the front. We learned that $10 will get you slot #7.  When only half the words to our duet came on, we asked for a refund or a free song. They explained that it's "the machine." No refund. Oh, you'd like another song? $2. Terrible. Go to Do Re Mil.

PSJ9LP_U3jF5K9avjvPPRw.review_text: This place is mainly great for karaoke & drinks.  Located at the end of the bridge between the Japantown malls, Festa is a small lounge with one bar and one karaoke stage, where most people hop on stage immediately or after a few drinks.  Overall, this place is great fun if you're into drinks and karaoke at night. Beware it's fairly small, where no more than 50 people can fit into this place. It's great to rent out for the night if you plan a birthday party!

wrhOaPospStRs5q15ot4bA.review_text: I will admit that before going here I'd only done karaoke once. I'm pretty sure I'm tone deaf, but the nice thing is at 1am after a bunch of drinking, it doesn't matter. Just sing with conviction and everyone will cheer you on.  I find the location (inside this odd indoor strip-mall thing) kind of weird, and the place is small and tacky - but maybe that's part of the charm?  Nothing else stands out about the place - so I'm only giving it 3 stars - but perfectly OK place to take a few friends out to get your karaoke kicks on.

m_H93eDKdiBlRv8K7Ffgsg.review_text: If after a big Italian meal and multiple bottles of Prosecco someone suggests it's time to pop your karaoke cherry, say 'yes'. If en route to a mysterious karaoke bar someone tells you it's in a Japanese strip mall, say 'bring it on'. If entering the mysterious karaoke bar it ends up looking like an airport watering hole in Tulsa mixed with a stage borrowed from bad nineties stand up, say 'hell yes'. If after a few songs you realize that you've unknowingly crashed somebody else's office party, say 'I can rock these bitches under the table.'  Pay particularly close attention to the completely unrelated b-roll footage that rolls behind the lyrics - it ranged from Demi Moore headshots during Total Eclipse of the Heart to water treatment plants during the Backstreet Boys. Or maybe it wasn't unrelated...  Staff were incredibly friendly which is great since the bartenders themselves are the ones managing the song order and making sure larger groups have enough microphones. That said, there were a couple of downsides in the overpriced drinks, the fact that performer names aren't announced so you need to bumrush the stage when you hear your song, multiple appearances of Baby Got Back, and the fact that you're pretty much guaranteed a hangover.

5PMiSCo8nXgf6VB1meCIGQ.review_text: Festa = Fun!!!  This little bar/lounge is located in the Japantown shopping mall.  The bartenders are super outgoing and fun and make you feel like they are your best friend by the end of the night.  Drinks were okay (lychee martini = yum, dirty martini = nasty).  It costs $2 to sing a song and, since there were only 10 people there, I sang 4 songs and my husband sang 2.  I definitely recommend this bar!

4GSnJSiWMWTpSAsLv3qR2g.review_text: This was the second time I've been to this "establishment". The first time me and my friends had a wonderful time. We were enjoying our drinks and performances. But last night... wow... me and my friends (the same ones from last time) decided to come here after a late dinner for some drinks and entertainment. Boy were we in for a treat! We came in it was pretty empty which we didnt think much of because it was a Wednesday night. This man (theres a picture of him in all black wearing a hat) came to seat us, we really didnt need his help being that only 2 tables were being occupied (we were waiting for the rest of our party, but we followed him to the table. He giggled and made our party show ID. So we were looking through the book of songs from "Septemeber 2008" and the waitress came over to take our drink orders. 2 people in our party didnt want to drink but she said "there's a one drink minimum" (which we didnt have before) so they ordered drinks and we moved on. So we waited a little while for our drinks, when they came the waitress spilled one of them on my friend. I had a mojito that was VERY watery and small for $9. Before we could finish our drinks she came to ask us about our bill. 2 people were together and the other 3 were with me. She came back with 3 checks, i had my card out already so i grabbed my two checks and handed it back to her... My other friend decided to keep her tab opened. So the waitress returned with my reciept I signed it. Left no tip becuz I was planning on leaving cash after I was done drinking. The waitress took the check. After the males in our group stepped out for a smoke, the giggling man came to our table and told me "Um, you didnt leave a  tip"; I told him "I know, I was going to leave cash when Im done" He then says "This is America, you need to leave a 20% tip!" Um... I don't recall seeing that in the constitution, so my response of shock and laughter was understandable. When our other friends come back we tell them the story and they laugh. So Im still there sipping on my mint water when one of our friends goes to get one more drink and to close their tab. The giggling man told him "Make sure she gives a tip" which my friend tells me. His wife is going over their tab and they were charged extra money. So we approach the bar because we are leaving; they tell her they charged her $3 tax for keeping their tab open... Now, to me this is something that  they should had stated when they decided to keep the tab open. So, in the end they over charged my friend and recieved no tip from me because they were very rude by asking me for a tip when I was not leaving. Guess I we will have to just find a neww spot because I will never be back to this place ever again!

96IKLbNHdK-sOAjuMwoegw.review_text: SELECTION OF SONGS GETS 5 STARS!!!! Never in my life have I seen such a huge selection of Crystal Kay and Amuro Namie jams to sing. I was in heaven!  When I first got there, it was about 8 or so so not many people were there yet. I had a saketini. It was OK. (After trying my 3rd saketini at this bar, I'm beginning to realize I'm not a fan of the saketini. Lol.) Luckily it was free bc some old Japanese dude bought it for me. Hooray!  Since there weren't alot of people in the beginning, there were many opportunities to sing. Everyone was really friendly and welcoming. I just got there that day and already I felt like I was at home. Is this what they talk about when they say friendly people live in San Francisco?  Maybe... but singing here does not come free.  Well, before I left, I was told to pay $2 PER SONG and the guy scribbled a bill on a scratch sheet of paper. I've been to so many karaoke places and never did I have to pay per song.
