I thought he was joking, laughed it off, and left the bar. Well, next thing you know, the guy follows me and shows up OUTSIDE of the bar still asking me to pay for the 5 songs I sang. He tells me I owe him $10 and his manager was going to get mad at him if he didn't pay for those 5 songs. I still think he was joking. He insisted he wasn't so I followed him to the bar so he could show me proof. O man o man. He wasn't joking!! In fine print, it says "$2 per song."   Ironically, I come in here later on to show this place to some random people who were wanting to karaoke. And apparently this happens alot. Another confused customer was listening to another worker from this bar explain about the $2 per song bill. Lol.   I was in Kinokuniya on Monday and I could hear people jamming it out here through the walls. Lol. I guess they are open everynight.  So, in short, I REALLY REALLY REALLY REALLY like this place for their very friendly atmosphere, extensive song collection listed by artist, and being open everynight. But I don't like it for their $2 per song deal.

UOvgLYlLJ3mKgwuih9E8hg.review_text: Music, booze & fun.  Thumbs up!  Atsuko knows how to concoct my poison.  I love this place.

tOMSnjbKoPGaDMqSFnpCiA.review_text: This was one of the worse places!  Not only were the drinks extremely pricey,  they added the gratuity already. Even on individual checks. Which would be fine, if it was posted somewhere. Not sure how 3 beers and 3 shots cost $78.  And it was $2 per song. Again would be fine, but if I paid $2 I assume I get to sing the song by myself. I put in a song and there was another girl singing with me. I asked her why she sang with me.  She put in that song too. And she did and she paid $2 also.  Huge rip off of a place. I would have even this place one star if yelp would let me.

24pirQC_JSQ-UunYOV5-6Q.review_text: After reading Jim's tomb below (pretty comprehensive stuff there!) I am not sure what else I can bring to the party. But I will say this much - I love karaoke, mostly consisting of the secret-room-where-no-one-but-close-friends-and-­loved-ones-can-see-me-make-a-fool-of-myself kind, but Festa opened my eyes to what the make-a-fool-of-yourself-in-front-of-everyone thing is all about. The drinks may be pricey (I just glommed onto someone else's big beer bottle orders) but the atmosphere totally makes it worth the cost. I even sang along to one of the few Japanese pop songs I can wrangle. I love Namie Amuro! Go. Have fun. Be a fool.

XrzkP-EPpql8cis-GlQ57A.review_text: Japantown looked so beautiful last night with all of the trees in bloom.  I attended a private party  last night at Festa Karaoke Bar.  People sang their hearts out while others consumed cocktails and sang along from the sidelines and cheered for their fellow co-workers.  It's a bit on the small side but yet so inviting, clean and friendly. Good times were had by all.  Yeah!

s6xZpSHNteqqsLzuC3Jd8A.review_text: This is my favorite karaoke bar! In the past few years, I have frequented this tiny joint many times to ham it up onstage and purr into the mic. $2 per song, supportive crowd and nice staff. "Gangsta's Paradise" is MY JAM!!!

6LDH0BvEy1IPsd3WsSOtJQ.review_text: This is def the best Karaoke place in the City!! I like how they are in obscurity in Japan town. This place is a little small but I like how it becomes like a private retreat.  Their wine and cocktail is good, and I love their Lychee martini!  The staff are welcome and friendly too.

a21yEFhTXEJImb9hGl0JyQ.review_text: Three dudes butchered my favorite Aerosmith song. Cutting their throats would have been wrong. This was going to be a short visit instead we stayed long. I work the next morning why the hell did I come along. F**k it i'm here now so help me belong. Yes, i'm Filipino and don't sing...You stupid ding dong. The size of this place is rather small and oblong. With plenty of room for mahjongg or beer pong. Bobby L sang so brave and so brawn. He'd be the sh*tz if he performed in Hong Kong. Thank you Badri, Hana, Bobby, and Chang (Chong). You wore a short skirt what color was that thong?  LMAO!  I'm being stupid!     Thank you Festa!   I'll be back!   Three stars for now!  And thank you Donna Y and Alex C for taking my drunk ass home back to San Jose!  =)

jXOcTKisD-R97eyHYNyU0w.review_text: let me tell you about the hazard that is Festa.  Suppose you go out with this guy and he totally surprises you by taking you to a kick-ass karaoke bar where the drinks are strong, the background is fittingly cheesy, and everyone is drunk and and singing along to the tone-deaf exhibitionist onstage. As you finish a round of drinks and get up to slur your way through a forgotten-favorite song, you think to yourself: this place is freakin' awesome.  A week or so later, you grab your friends and introduce them to this glorious world of alcohol-filled public embarrassment. And again, it is awesome beyond comprehension.  A few weeks pass, and you haven't been to Festa in a while. A visit is long overdue! You enter the tiny place, and to your horror you recognize more than half of the people there. You realize that, like wildfire or syphilis, word has spread from one friend to another, and before you know it, you're performing to a packed house of vague acquaintances and semi-friends.  Damnit, people, karaoke bars are for anonymous idiocy, where there is no fear of negative backlash or the need for damage control in the days following!  And thus, am I going to have to say: The first rule of Festa is: YOU DO NOT TALK ABOUT FESTA.  Thank you and goodnight.

vYTgM0Oke2pcd0X33yEcaA.review_text: we had a very similar experience to other reviews here., surprisingly high priced drinks for the atmosphere/service and extra drink charges on the bill.  The bartender also refused to fix the bill for us.

dC5kYsLGGoLLVlMjeMqfLw.review_text: C'mon...who doesn't love singing in front of a bunch of strangers?   A few things... *pretty small place...only about 10 tables. Would suggest getting there before 9p on the weekends if you want a seat.  *each song is $2, but the list is long. They have every decade, as we'll as show tunes.  *affordable drinks...and pretty quick service at bar and table.   Overall...great service, fun atmosphere and large song book. Time to get your sing on!

tkcUGC5N4WvUPlSG-KCfhw.review_text: Came here on my birthday last summer with a few friends after dinner and never had the chance to review. It's  a very small and intimate place where people can get drinks and karaoke which is located inside of Japantown plaza.   Although most karaoke places have many rooms where people sing for their own privacy. Not this place!! You pick a song from the folders and when it's your turn, you go up to the small stage and you sing in front of everyone. It's very entertaining just watching those people sing no matter how good or how bad they sing. You have to be 21 to get into this place if you want to sing since they serve alcohol drinks.   If you order drinks, it's a bit pricy. I order Pear Cosmo for $9. I order this drink cause I never cosmo with pear flavor and also thought it'll be a sweet kind of cocktail. I was sure wrong. You can really taste the volka strong alcohol taste which made it harder for me to drink.

-OS9MY0ZfvMFh8UpiAeb5g.review_text: As folks have mentioned, $2 a song, but what a selection!  They have a CyberDam system for all those who need to scratch the J-Pop itch (I'm a bit of a Hirai Ken junkie), and another system for more recent English songs. The Japanese system also has a better-than-average selection of songs in other languages.  If I'm in Japantown, it's a great follow-up to dinner.

x6_8-SBS55EU4xNIjS2rrA.review_text: ******UPDATE***** Was 2 stars.. Now 1, after essentially being called a liar.   We had a few friends with us but if there are 2 glasses, 1 bottle, 1 bill and no wait staff there shouldn't be an auto gratuity, let alone 30%!!!!! Bad business practices...  Shame shame shame  ****************  I think without my bad experience this would be 3 stars but experience shapes the review so 2 it is.   I have been here before and had a great time.  We come, we karaoke, we drink, we laugh... Good times.   The last time I came here it was a tad off.  Firstly, it was crowded, which is good for business but I think that's a sign that the *****DJs shouldn't sing in between people.*****  It takes up room for the patrons to sing... Not all of my friends got a chance to sing and I had a party of 6 and we were there for 3 hours.  Secondly, the song selection is very weak and you can't hear yourself sing. No Roy Orbison?  Thirdly, they start cleaning and kicking people out right at 1:30 am.  I hadn't finished my very expensive champagne and I was being ushered out!  They did try and be nice about having poor customer service saying  its the law and all this business about their license... I get it, but how is their licensing so different from any other joint in SF? Whatever.. Fourthly, this is the worst part... When they asked for my card to close my tab I did as I was told.  I bought one bottle of my favorite champagne for $80... They handed me the receipt to sign and said they added gratuity....??????????? I shared 1 bottle of champagne with my boyfriend!!!!! And they charged me 30% gratuity without asking!!!!!!!! 30% ?! ?!?!  Where do you get a number like that and why do you charge your patrons a gratuity?!! I filled our glasses each time... I shouldn't have to tip them $30 for walking a bottle 3 feet from the bar to my table, right?!?! And not have a say?!?! Of course when I try to dispute this I am ushered away and out,  not even able to finish my last glass.  Very bad service!!! The readers of this review may wonder why there is 2 stars instead of 1..... Well, the fact they HAD my favorite champagne for sale at a karaoke joint is notable.  And I did have fun, more because of my friends and the other patrons but never the less... I will not come back!  There are way too many karaoke joints.. Ones that stay open till 4 am... That won't charge your party of two 30% gratuity .

KiiaeP1jVSKgNSXzHTZ5kw.review_text: Did i miss the memo that karaoke is charged by the SONG?? what the hell?? the drinks  were supremely overpriced and the staff was a little snobby. i guess it used to be a little lower key coming to Festa, but unless you're in to drop a hundred dollar bar tab, skip it and go elsewhere

EA3pUAO5kubhX4rYO_BICw.review_text: Great little karaoke bar!! Extensive song list to choose that perfect song and impress the crowd with your awesomely alcohol induced voice!! Bartender was nice and very attentive when drinks were running low.

Dp9vtkpgNti0BuG3202PGQ.review_text: Very cool 70s retro + loungey karaoke bar in the middle of the Japantown mall.  The drinks are a bit pricey and they charge $2 per song for karaoke, but the singers were all entertaining (esp Corey) and the bar offers a welcome respite from the mall atmosphere.

JckM9f0L5q5xJR_lcsfB7Q.review_text: I honestly do not understand the low scores given to Festa so far. I've found the staff to be attentive and fun, the drinks strong and delicious, and the song selection better than almost every karaoke place I've been to in the city. The stage can seem intimidating but the truth is the crowd and staff always appreciate and applaud every performance. Very accommodating, fun, and festive!

TJ7vY6598yC_mdh1eIK09w.review_text: It's my favorite bar in San Francisco. Nice wine selection, the staff is very friendly and accommodating. I always have a great night there when I'm the area.

MhXQCjMV2uio3rr2IvdYvQ.review_text: I was there last saturday and the bartender called one of my friends a jackass after he left for no reason. After i asked him why, he was very unapologetic and was then rude to the girls I was with. None of us had any bad interactions with this bartender that night so he was just taking out some aggression on us. Not worth your time. A far better place is Town Studio right around the corner for Karaoke. Great place and extremely friendly staff. Don't waste your time here.

6q3RKPxoCV8ZxSFkILg1eg.review_text: I've been passing the place by in J-town for a good number of years, without realzing what this place really was.   After an evening of hopping lounges and karaoke bars, my group decided to head here to finish off the night. The prices are a lot cheaper than renting private rooms and the stage and lounge area is intimate enough to where you don't feel intimdiating standing up on stage. I thought the sound equipment was also a lot better, although, a few additional screens (namely in front of you) would have been better than having to keep looking off to the side on a smallish screen on a shelf for lyrics.   Again, great intimate lounge with some of the best singers I've heard yet (aside from Martuni's) and at only $2 bucks a song, you truly only pay for the songs you end up singing. The drinks are obviously still pricey as with any bar/lounges are, however, since I'm not into drinker, I was able to just pay for my songs and then leave whenever I wanted.   Overall, it was a great first experience here and I even made some a few fans at the end of the night! :)  PS. If you're going to be doing karaoke late night 9pm+, I highly recommend parking in the J-town garage which charges only $1 late night hours. It's a lot more secure than parking on the street around here!

nqHHZRKZ3cGlmzzbBFMdvw.review_text: Nice design for such a small place. However, beware of the cost. In addition to the $9 well drinks (and you'll be sold bottled water if you ask for water), there can be a cover charge of $10 per person, plus a charge of $2.00 per song, should the owner choose! Was totally surprised when asked to pay for selecting a song at a karaoke bar!

qkreXL6AorI19QA3f2wvlQ.review_text: Awesome song selection in 3 languages!  I went here with the regulars (the ones that have their own song book selection) and i had such a great time belting it out!  The weekday crowd was non judgmental and encouraging.. Someone even asked me to sing again!  I had a delicious bellini, which was $10.  I believe there is a one drink minimum.  And Atsuko, one of the bartenders, was fun to hang out with.  I'll definitely come here again!

qVMqPrHedv8pYOtf5FAaCA.review_text: I always have a good time here.  The bartenders are excellent, I'm always telling my friends this is a great place to get a drink.  As others have said, the drinks are $8-$12 but the quality is high, in my experience.  And the staff are very friendly and quick to serve.  This is a fantastic place to bring a small group of friends (recommend a weeknight - the weekends get crazy).  Very warm, cozy atmosphere and you get to sing often.

ZzYZaE8P-zV2AXfN3WTfAg.review_text: Love Love Love this place!!! I have been inspired to take singing lessons and learn Japanese after staying at this place at this place for hours when I only randomly walked in with a friend to see what this place was about.  I plan on making this a regular hangout!!! The owner and the service is awesome and the crowd is friendly. This little gem of a venue is going to be discovered by the rest of San Francisco soon...

UzG5IHFUu6H1UyCRbqHHZw.review_text: for a while now, late at night, i've walked into the sleepy kinokuniya building (thanks for the introduction, jason c!)...  goodnight, sophie's crepes.  goodnight, kinokuniya bookstore.  festa, you're still awake?  fantastic.  i'd like to tell you about my day via song over a bottle of sake.  ...and that's how everyone should embrace festa.  it is the emotive haven for all.  whether you're heartbroken fools (who request 'always' by atlantic starr) or middle-aged businessmen who just came from gold club (who request 'i'm in love w/a stripper' by t-pain), this is where you are welcome.  ....except for the obnoxiously drunk.  you belong in a private karaoke room.  w/acoustically enhanced walls.  and linoleum floors.    are you a karaokein fool?  songs are free before 9pm during the weekdays ($2/song otherwise).  if you see me there, let's sing a duet!  : )

En6ApCOKEHIM7Ea24uXuUg.review_text: Hands down the best Karaoke bar in California, let alone San Francisco, possibly the WHOLE world! For all the one-star no-life, haters below, if you come to a karaoke bar expecting white-tablecloth customer service, well, you have a one-star brain! The point of this place is that you come, have a fantastic time, sing your heart-out right before you black out, and be sure to black out so that the next time you come back it's all new to you, so even if you did have shitty service - who cares! And on that note, in fact, the staff are awesome, good friends, great people, lovers, and Masae is simply the best. Rock-on Festa - I think I have been there, but I never can quite remember. LOVE IT!

2--3--v8yHU3a3FljCcBRg.review_text: WHOA totally didn't notice I hit the 100 review mark and didn't do anything for it!  Oh well, for my one hundred and FIRST review I will write about a little karaoke bar called FESTA.    Came here for Aileen's unbirthday last weekend and it was pretty awesome.  Not only did our group of 8 make up practically 50% of the patrons, but by the end of the night we were friends with (almost) everyone else at the bar.  Yes, that includes the table of world travelers from Japan and Germany, the table of SoCal Koreans, and the brave solo artists at the bar.  It does not however, include the group of hooligans in newsboy caps and plaid scarves who thought singing as loudly and as annoyingly as possible would make everyone like them.  I guess that only works in the movies.    All in all it's a chill place and an (almost) judgment-free zone for the performers.  Drinks are pricey but hey it's Japantown.  Also, there's a 10 dollar cover if you wanna reserve a table (comes with 2 free songs).  I think they lowered it to 8 bucks for us though because we were awesome or something.    Songs are 2 bucks each if you're buying them a la carte.  Never been to a karaoke bar where you had to pay for the individual song.  But then again I don't go out that much.  Only enough to make it to my ONE HUNDRED AND FIRST YELP REVIEW.  WOOP WOOP!!  Thanks for the memories, y'allz!

Et26UlD026zi8sinFl_NdA.review_text: This is the best place to sing Karaoke in SF. Small and intimate setting, it's about the size of one of the larger karaoke boxes in Tokyo. Staff is friendly and fun, song selection is very good in both English and Japanese. The overall atmosphere is very Japan-like, including the Tokyo pricing of the drinks, and their willingness to "over serve" their customers. What I like most about it is the people who go here are fun and cool, and everyone is getting their rock star on.

hvOlTjSeucPuK_LJC7fU8w.review_text: Entertaining for sure, if the right person and/or song is up.  We came here after dinner at Benihana and continued the birthday festivities.  About a third of our group were willing to take the stage.  The rest seemed content to watch and laugh (and probably inwardly smirk).  I did brave the stage - only for the birthday girl - and had a good time.  Of course, the song we picked seemed to last forever, but I hope we got an A for effort...  Songs you think may be easy to sing take on a different challenge when you're actually on stage.  However, the crowd was very friendly and encouraging, even to the worst acts.  Guts!  So take a swig of beer and then ante yourself up to belt out a few tunes.  Sweeeeeet Caroliiiiiine!!!

yUEST-mxyXkK_3f-qwTtgg.review_text: Randomly walking around, after visiting Harry's Bar up Fillmore, the peeps and I were looking for something to do in the area.  We were walking down Post, when we heard some noise 'singing' upstairs in the Kinokuniya building.  We decided to check it out, not knowing what to expect.  Alas, a karaoke bar! We decided to stay. The crowd was young, and the mood was right. We ordered the best Sapporo's I've ever had, nice and cold in a frozen glass. Then some pro decided to bust out some Whitney Houston on the karaoke, and then they closed. Didn't realize it was getting late.  Anyway, this place was great, cozy, and fun. Didn't sing, but we were just there looking for some entertainment over drinks.

cWoTq95aJuNKT26cZnxbAA.review_text: I looooooove this place!!!! I have been to quite a few karaoke joints and this one, I have to say, hands down, makes me feel so comfortable and at home and I keep wanting to go back. I love that it's sort of hidden, off the beaten path. It's kind of small and cozy...not intimidating for non-pro singers if you get my drift. The staff is very attentive, classy and also fun. They sometimes sing themselves! The drinks are really well done. I get a lemon drop ever time...done to perfection. This place is in my neighborhood which I love. I have had many many friends come here and we've all had the best time. Each night is slightly different of course. Weekends are more crowded and get big groups sometimes. Weekdays are nice, a mixture of people just getting off there bartending/waitressing jobs nearby, people staying at the nearby hotel and locals wandering in. EVERYTIME I have been here, what I have been impressed by is the support of the crowd. It can be all types of people, old and young, all ethnicities and we're all cheering each other on whether good or bad. It's a real confidence booster to get on stage and sing your heart out and have adoring fans around. A real nice way to let loose. I did read some of the other reviews on here before I wrote this and I almost wish I didn't because I'm saddened to see how they diss the staff. You have to know this staff deals with people yelling into the mic and getting a bit carried away in intoxication at times. They are trying to accommodate new comers and trying to please everyone. So I don't find it unreasonable that they accommodate as they see appropriate. I am so happy and proud to have this relatively new restaurant in my neighborhood. It is one of the finer new establishments to bring the Fillmore district back to life in a positive sense. I have come here for brunch, dinner dates, a company Christmas party, for the drinks at the bar and for apps and drinks in the lounge area. I love decor: the historical jazz pictures with the light behind them on the walls, the unique decorative hanging lamps, and the dark wood. I really like the way this place sections off to make it more intimate whether for private parties or if it's not that buy and they close off certain sections. Oh, the music is jazzy of course. Romantic, classic, soulful, happy and fun. The staff are cheery, helpful and knowledgeable. Ok, the best for last...the food is AMAZING! I have gotten the pork main (YUM!), the shrimp and grits app (YUM!) and the butternut squash soup (YUM again!). I've gotten a lot more than that but that's what comes to mind..haven't had anything bad or even mediocre there basically. This a really classy without being pretentious place and I highly recommend you go there NOW!

HKC-j6ShF_wUfB0q1BH5cw.review_text: Frank Sinatra probably started off small. It must have been on one of those tiny stages like they have at Festa - you're in the spot light, but it still feels intimate. The drinks are good, the crowd fun and relaxed. And they definitely get loose the later it gets.  Sadly, during my many visits there I only felt like Frank Sinatra ONCE - when I was performing a classic that I can't remember. Nowadays, I'm mostly content with sitting and enjoying the performances that range from close-to-ear-damage to San-Francisco's-Got-Talent.  Festa's extensive list of songs provide fun for nights to come. Get your Frank Sinatra on and hop on stage.

PadmV2GEoA6mWpQUpPh7Ig.review_text: I am probably one of the few Filipinos who can't sing. And not only that... I've always refused to sing. And how i wish i could!!!!   You know how like when you're little and it's your grandma's birthday, and your mother would ask you to sing as a cutesy little present?? yeah. that scenario. My mom bribes me with Money just to sing. And it was an epic fail for her. I would still never ever Sing. (I played the piano instead and bowed- or recited a poem --and if i weren't cranky, danced to the beat of whatever in a ruffled skirt)  However. people change. Monica grew up and learned not to give a f*ck and what not.   And coz Yelp friends are pushy (in a good way). and with them and karaoke, i am a pushover.  And at Festa... man...if i could only hog the mic for the whole night, I would. That mini stage...that gigantic, super updated songbook (They had Rolling in the Deep by Adele!!! - but that's for my next show ya guys -- when I'm not driving and i can drink and be drunk)... the awesome crowd who clap no matter how crazy one sings... the awesome bartenders....the clean restroom...the yummy cocktails....the comfy lounge chairs...  I love FESTA!!!!!

Q1OcZih_TjD3VmL0enjKVA.review_text: Was walking through J-Town and heard singing so we stopped by to check it out and ended up staying.  It was fun watching people do karoake - there were alot that were American Idol standard!!!  Its entertaining.  The place is well decorated, very cozy, and good ambience.  We would go again.

s1mD1PvJQrAYHfNG9UDYJw.review_text: Overall, Festa can be a fun place, but get this:  One night, my friend couldn't drink anything alcoholic for some reason (I forget why), so he ordered a plain Diet Coke. Guess how much he was charged? $5. It was straight out of a can too. He thought, "Well, if you're going to make a 500% profit off of a can of soda, can I at least have the rest of the can?" The answer is "NO." What kind of world do we live in? How do you say "wrong" in Japanese?

jt49xjEjQisu6wTTGn6B3A.review_text: The drinks are strong with this one. Oh so very strong. Like, my head hurt for a solid day after a night of drinking/karaoking here. But boy was it fun at the time!  The downside, of course, is that the drinks are pricey. But you won't need many glasses of liquid courage to get on up and sing!  The space is small, looking pretty airport loungey, but that's part of it's charm. Teeny stage, a few tables huddled around it. You'll most likely get pretty intimate with someone you don't know as it gets standing room only pretty quickly. Another bonus of the small space is that it doesn't take long for your song to come up since it doesn't fit very many.  The staff is super nice, the bartenders chatty and friendly. The biggest issue that I have is that you have to pay to sing! 2 bucks a song. Maybe I haven't been to enough karaoke only places and this is the norm but round Michigan the singin' is free (although I have been known to tip the karaoke master from time to time). So to have to pay was a little bit of a surprise. The staff runs the karaoke too, so it's not like they're paying someone separate. Hmm.  Otherwise it's a great place to enjoy a night out with friends, new and old. Karaoke is a fabulous ice breaker, dontcha know??

5Ug6Dy69REkQ4c3tFabKdQ.review_text: Hands down the worst customer service I've ever had at a bar in San Francisco.  I came in with a large group but had no intention of ordering anything even though other people were.  My friend and I asked for tap water, and the waitress brought us bottled water that she wanted us to pay for.  We refused it and politely clarified that we wanted tap water.  She came back with two Sapporos.  What?? Fine. We'll take the Sapporos, which she said (and the menu said) were $6 each.  (Reading the reviews I now realize there is a drink minimum so maybe that's why she did this, although that was not made clear to me).  I gave her my credit card, and she came back with a bill for $15.50.  $15.50?!  When I challenged it, she said I had to pay 18% gratuity because I was sitting with a large group.  But I was ordering as a party of 2!! I wasn't paying for everyone's drinks!  And even so, $12 plus 18% gratuity is $14.16, not $15.50.  I obviously refused to pay this.  Then she had the gall to come back with a $13 check, which was STILL ripping me off (since drinks aren't supposed to be taxed in a non-restaurant, and there's no way sales tax on two drinks is an even $1), but I was too fed up to protest more.  Absolutely appalling. On top of all this, they charge $2 per song and have a pretty lame selection of music.  This place does not deserve your business.

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: $12 for a well dirty martini? Unless their bottom barrel vodka is Grey Goose, me thinks not.   Still a great spot for a fun night of karaoke, but some recent service failures have taken a bit of wind from out of my sails.

hhIYp_VDKZSzMecFF3YJAg.review_text: Totally agree with Brenda T. regarding Festa Cocktail Lounge!  I've never been to any Karaoke that charges customers $2 per song that they sing. I have been to Karaoke bars which are more upscale than this one wherein you get private rooms to use and sing your lungs out but does not charge for the number of songs you would want to sing.  Not coming back.

SdX6ZlW4YHwZf75-S5eO7w.review_text: I came this place for friend birthday I really love this tiny karaoke bar. So many selection of song and sound system was best !!!

Bp-TQEtc6Vs6ldnLgjqglg.review_text: can two people step into a karaoke bar on a friday night, not sing, and STILL have a great time?   the answer is a resounding, YES.   they have the best j-video collection of songs i have ever seen, and the bar is intimate and fun. a lot of older japanese men mixed in with the crazy young and boisterous crowd.   the bartenders are super cool and everyone in the bar is extremely friendly.

3bRM3cStV70e8utZpOemCw.review_text: WHOAH. Was this place shady? Check yes!  I have been here a few occasions prior and had quite a pleasant evening, but apparently when you bring a large group of thirsty divas the shit hits the fan.  Yes, this place is cute, small, and the decorative atmosphere is lovely, but when taking into account the snobbery and rudeness of the people that work here, I will never ever come here again. And I highly recommend that you stray away from such businesses.  Shady example 1:  The large group that we were with opened a number of tabs. The same drinks were charged on multiple tabs. Sure, they wanted to take more of our money for booze, but they definitely weren't overwhelmingly excited to play the songs our party requested.  Shady example 2:  A friend of mine opened her own tab with a few drinks, put in a song when she arrived, and waited two hours. Her song never came up. People that came to the place AFTER her got multiple songs in. Upon asking the "KJ" if he lost it, he was--apparently--quite rude.  Shady example 3:  There were a number of tables reserved for the evening. That's fine. They sat us in the reserved section and said, "At 11:30 you'll have to find another table or stand." That was no big deal at that point. Come 11:30, we all get up and move to another section of the bar. I was sitting at a table for about 10 minutes, and the owner came up to me, placed a reserved place card, and said, "This table is reserved, you're going to have to move." She then goes to MY FRIENDS (who came later than the first wave of people) that I INVITED (to spend money at her corrupt establishment) and asks ME to move so they could sit down. It's a good thing I knew these people, seeing as they walked into the bar after me, or I would have been so much more disappointed than I already was. It was such a dick move--her judgment of socioeconomic class was very apparent as she asked the casually dressed brown man to move for the "classier" dressed white girls.  All in all, don't come to this place unless you're already friends with that owner that has the worst stink face I have ever seen. This place could really be awesome if the owner wasn't corrupt in her business decisions.

gBEihTFxWQ5CzOH1tGjAPw.review_text: 4 Stars + Open Late + Large Selection of Songs + Good Service + Accepts Credit Cards + Happy Hour +/- Open Mic haha - No Private Rooms - Small My girlfriends and I found  this place after having dinner in Japantown a few weeks back. We originally walked in to get a few drinks and then realized it was a karaoke bar also! Great haha. Drinks we ordered were: White Peach Bellini (White Peach and Sparkling Wine) $10 yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTX…, Pomegrandetini (Vodka, Pomegrande, and Lemon Juice)  $9  yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTX… Tokyo (Vodka, Pineapple Juice, and Blue Curacao) $9 yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTX… and Ginger Lemon Drop  (Lemon Flavored Vodka, Lemon Juice, and Ginger Syrup) $9 yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTX…. There weren't that many people in when we arrived so we were lucky enough to sing a few songs on stage. They have a pretty large selection of songs to choose from. English, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, you name it. Festa is open mic, therefore no private rooms and everyone gets up see you sing haha. Happy hour for free Karaoke starts from 7:30 pm and 9:00 pm.

a2DI4ToFCOMnxXqsu4Ur5Q.review_text: Terrible! Rude owner and bar tenders! Is it that hard to be nice when we're paying way to much for bad drinks and paying two bucks per song to do Karaoke? It shouldn't be. I will not go here again, unless they get now ownership and staff, and better drinks. Booooooo  I can't stand this place!

j6wBhprUCU3XC7aQe8u6Qw.review_text: We've been to this place twice and  our experience could not have been more different. The first time we went, we found it to be one of the only authentic karaoke bars in Japantown that did not serve as a brothel on the side and we had a terrific time singing with the owner and buying our $6-$8 drinks. However, we went there tonight with a group of friends and when our final tab came, the bartender took the priveledge of charging us $10 a drink, added on drinks that we paid in cash to our friends' tab, and charged us $2 a song without ever notifying us of the "karaoke song" charge in the first place. We will never go there again and would advise likewise.

vgkevqurpV4oZur0ThA-pQ.review_text: I've learned some tough lessons at Festa.  Japanese businessmen love songs by Britney Spears and will get up and dance with you making you feel like the young, hot version of Britney - not the freaky, can't keep her children, shave her head Britney.    Japanese businessmen do NOT, however, like Barry Manilow.  They will stare at you stonefaced and make you feel like a fallen star.  They are probably right.

P_0MidHAEbcO8gmHE6eQcw.review_text: The familiar warble of a karaoke song wafted out a nondescript set of doors, catching my attention as I was walking towards the parking garage. My curiosity was piqued, and I forged through the veneer to find myself transported to a bar in Tokyo. My friend was similarly delighted with the kitschy skyline decor and fabulously modern red chairs. We settled in quickly even though there weren't a lot of patrons around, and after a bottle of delightful sake called "poochi poochi" we took to the mike stand and never looked back. More of the bar's regulars strolled in later in the evening, and none shied away from belting out some classic oldies as well as more current tunes. I ended up spending a pretty penny there but I don't think I can say it wasn't worth it.

jPG9VvKCfp4RAMuaRFD91Q.review_text: Anyone who knows me well knows that I LOVE to karaoke.  Though I usually prefer singing in a room with just my friends, there's something exhilarating about getting up in front of a crowd of strangers.  I've introduced many friends to Festa and everyone has enjoyed coming here, as far as I know.  They keep pretty up-to-date on their songs, but also maintain a nice list of the classics.    So, this is how it works: you write your song on a slip of paper, hand it to the staff at the bar, and wait nervously for your song to play.  While waiting and feeling somewhat regretful for the situation you just put yourself in, you end up downing a beer or taking a (few) shot(s) to calm your nerves.  By the time your song is up, you're too buzzed/drunk to even care; as far as you know, you rocked it!  It's a formula for a great night, if I do say so myself.  Drinks are a bit pricey here; you can easily rack up a hefty bill between drinks and songs, which cost $2 each (free before 9 on M-Th, I believe).  It's always a fun time though, and the patrons here are always nice and supportive of whoever is up on stage singing, so don't be shy!

fSvOdnryI9FPJ2ylcsE2ig.review_text: Love this place. It's intimate and they have a full bar. Costs $2 per song and sometimes you do wait awhile. Go early and get your songs in. Their list of songs is huge too. You go up on stage and can sing to your heart's content. I hate singing, but I got up there to sing with friends, of course. Great find in J-Town and way classier than do re mi (ew disgusting!)

2bHSZhM0huV8LRh3YHaOSQ.review_text: Dark, swanky, sexy. . . excellent backdrop of lit up city skyline for singing Japanese karaoke.  I don't know about you guys, but I can't read or pronounce Japanese characters, so add that to the fact that I don't know any of the songs, and this will make for some damn obnoxious (or entertaining) karaoke. Add it to the JTown Crawl. **Update** I'm going with damn obnoxious karaoke.  We did indeed add this spot to the JTown Crawl on Friday.  What I have only seen as a dark lounge filled with a couple of businessmen during the week, but have heard as a noisy hotspot on weekends or later in the evening, proved its hotspot chops.  But not with the crowd I'm used to seeing.  It seems to me that Silver Cloud got too crowded for some of the more SF savvy karaoksters and they've moved on to more intimate pastures.  Unfortunately for the rest of us.   We perched at a corner table for just a moment before the waitress asked if we'd like to sit in the corner booth (which had a reserved sign on it).  Boy did we!  We snuggled in and placed our order and waited to watch some folks sing their hearts out.   I only made it through two lychee martinis (which were excellent, even if the lychees themselves were too sweet for me - canned it seems) and a little bowl of "outlines" which I ordered based on their name alone.  It's just snack mix - sesame stix, breadsticks, pretzels and nuts.  Why they call them outlines I have no idea, must be something lost in translation, but I love that they do.  It made them that much more delicious.   As for enjoying the dulcet sounds of undiscovered American Idols, those dreams were shattered as we winced through our evening.  Two large groups of drunk and obnoxious white folk took turns singing, reading lyrics in monotone spoken word style, and/or screaming and grunting into the mics.   Luckily you need do nothing more than catch a bartenders roving eye and signal for another drink when you're dry.  If I had to get up and wade through the boisterous crowd and their cupcakey fingers I would've only had the one drink. I think I'm only grousing because I was hoping for the quieter, more singing based karaoke experience I had seen on previous stops, instead of the Marina spillover screamfest/microphone fight we ended up with.  Oh and because we were the only couple in the entire place that didn't get offered birthday cupcakes.  What's up with that?  That's just mean.

3c3w_jRC2PwrA2MmC7ChGQ.review_text: Ordinarily, I'm pretty much scared shitless at the though of standing up in front of a crowd of strangers and singing karaoke. This place is just cozy enough, however, that it really rubs the edges off of my stage fright.   The cocktails are little bit weak, considering the price tag ($9-12).   They really reverb up the mics to sweeten your voice.   One time I sang Just Like Heaven, and ended up singing into both mics at once. I think I even sat down on the stage for a little bit. It must've made a pretty strong impression on my friend Dan, because he brings it up every time this place gets mentioned.   One of these days I'm going to find a song that I can flap my arms and jump up and down to.   Their English-language pop menu somehow skews towards a slightly new-wave/alternative sort of vibe. For instance, you can find Jon Spencer Blues Explosion songs on their menu, but no Space Oddity.   What am I gonna fatally embarrass myself with if there's no Space Oddity?
